Achune

Achune are massive sea turtles, famous for slowly roaming the coasts and seas of Braven. They are among the most collossal beasts known to common folk, and every culture on the Sea has some form of legends or lore about them. Achune have a thick shell on their back that often has small micro-habitats or even dwellings for other creatures and nomads. Achune are generally welcoming to passengers or passerbys, but always do their own thing (they are not tameable).

Friendly Alphas

Passive: 30 Nature*

Analyze: 60 Nature

Achune coexist with many other creatures and have no natural predators once fully grown.

Passionate

Passive: 40 Nature

Analyze: 70 Nature

Achune are fierce, monogamous lovers. Offending or attacking their mate is very dangerous.

Migrates Yearly

Passive: 50 Nature

Analyze: 100 Nature

Achune migrate along the coast of the Braven Sea, taking a full year to circle it. This can be a cheap source of transportation for the patient.

“The Mother - a significant locus of both human and achune culture. All with a heart respect it.”

- Eoghan Scrivener, On Creatures

Behavior

Achune mate for life in pairs and each achune is referred to as either “top” or “bottom.” The bottom achune can be the size of an island and they are quite gentle, mild mannered, and calm.

Tops are between four and ten times smaller (but still colossal) and literally live atop their mate’s shell. While tops are more aggressive, they mostly serve as the “social” member of the pair - greeting and setting boundaries with others.

Habitat and Life

Achune develop sexual organs after they are fully grown and have chosen a mate, late in life. They can even change again several times over.

Achune live in the Braven Sea exclusively and only come on land to lay eggs. Achune are rarely concerned for their children and often will lay their eggs and then continue migrating.

Achune are omnivores and eat pretty much anything that lives in the sea. They have been known to eat humans, but this is extremely rare.

Histories and Cultures

Many cultures write of achune, and some have even worshipped them through history. There have been legends of adventurers who befriended these gentle giants by helping protect their young as they crawl from their nest to the sea or even by cleaning up bad spirits that live on the backs of the bottoms.

Some cultures believe that the achune regard the Mother as a sort of holy land, with their yearly migration as a pilgrimage of sorts.

Notes for Playing as

Think “gentle and kind” for the most part. Perhaps if they are mean, it is because there is something they don’t like hiding on their shell.

Stable

Passive: 60 Nature or 70 Essence

Analyze: 110 Nature

Achune are immune to any spell or ability that could alter their mind, unless they consent.

Weak to Poison

Passive: 80 Nature or 70 Alchemy

Analyze: 130 Nature

Achune are rarely exposed to pollutants or poisons and take 5x effects (only when ingested).

Emanate Essence

Passive: 100 Nature & 100 Essence

Analyze: 170 Nature

The passionate spirits of living and dead Achune create environmental essence fields that will animate any corpses on their back into Deathless.

Achune Hatchling

Bite

12PT

Damage: [24 Health + 3d20+195 Stamina]

Info: Bite Attack (ML), 6 Base PT

Bunker Down2

9PT

Put head and limbs into shell, making them untargetable. Lasts until Chest reaches 0 Health or cancelled. Cannot use Bite during Bunker Down.

Cry Out2

3PT, 6SN

Any Achune within hearing range will come to the hatchling’s aid. Has a 5% chance to crit and guarantee summoning another hatchling.

~Passives~

Prime Trait, Size Advantage, Size Disadvantage, Water-loving

Receive 2x Health and Stamina healing.

Huge: Attacks have +1 Melee Range.

Huge: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Small-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost much more PT.

Can hold your breath three times as long. Swimming costs normal Move.

2nd Wind I+II+III, Brawn, Lrg. than Life, Prime Trait, Size Advantage, Size Disadvantage, Water-loving

Once per day when Stamina reaches below 3750, heal [80d20+1600 Stamina]. Once per day when Sanity reaches below 0, stay at 0. Once per day when Death Health reaches 0, heal [16d20 Health] (trait mult included).

Double Trauma effects.

Receive 50% Stun and Bleeding effects.

Receive 2x Health and Stamina healing.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +2 Melee Range and will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

Can hold your breath three times as long. Swimming costs normal Move.

Level 80

18PT, 12SN

Info: Bite Attack (IM), 6 Base PT

Bunker Down2

18PT, Opt: +18PT, +3d6SN

Put head and limbs into shell, making them untargetable. Lasts until Chest reaches 0 Health or cancelled. Can use Cry Out and Roll during Bunker Down.

Optional: At any time while bunkered, spend an additional [18PT] and [3d6SN] to heal [2000 Stamina] and remove [6d6 Bleeding].

Cry Out2

6PT, 6SN

If you have a mate, they will come to your aid. Has a 5% chance to crit and guarantee summoning an Achune Youth.

Lash

12PT

Damage: [6d20+1600 Stamina]

Info: Limb Attack (SM), 6 Base PT

Ram

18PT, 60SN

Damage: [24d20+2100 Stamina]

Info: Tackle Attack (SM), 6 Base PT, [15u] wide

Effects: Can only be used after movement. Causes knockdown to Collossal/Immense sized creatures along body’s width, or 1d20 knockback otherwise.

2nd Wind I+II+III, Brawn/Violent, Lrg. than Life, Prime Trait, Size Advantage, Size Disadvantage, Water-loving

Triple Trauma effects.

Receive 50% Stun and Bleeding effects.

Receive 2x Health and Stamina healing.

Colossal: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +3 Melee Range and may hit every unit up to that range. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Colossal: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Large-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost significantly more PT.

Can hold your breath three times as long. Swimming costs normal Move.

Achune Bottom

Level 100

Languages

Colonial (1), The Sea (3), & Therion (3)

Occupies: 30x30x10 (30u wide, 30u deep, 10u tall).

Bite

20PT, 12SN

Damage: [60 Health + 8d20+2800 Stamina]

Info: Bite Attack (ML), 6 Base PT

Bunker Down2

18PT, Opt: +18PT, +3d6SN

Put head and limbs into shell, making them untargetable. Lasts until Chest reaches 0 Health or cancelled. Can use Cry Out and Roll during Bunker Down.

Optional: At any time while bunkered, spend an additional [18PT] and [3d6SN] to heal [2000 Stamina] and remove [6d6 Bleeding].

Cry Out2

6PT, 6SN

If you have a mate, they will come to your aid. If they have already come to your aid, you grant them [+4d20] to their next maneuver.

Lash

14PT

Damage: [6d20+1600 Stamina]

Info: Limb Attack (SM), 6 Base PT

Emanate

20PT, 100SN

All corpses and husks residing on your back animate as deathless to defend you and your mate. Your deathless won’t attack anything you wish to remain unharmed, but will attack what they want otherwise. Lasts 3 rounds.

Colossal: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Large-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost significantly more PT.

Can hold your breath three times as long. Swimming costs normal Move.

Awoor

Awoor are small, vicious beasts once considered the single greatest threat to life for the inhabitants of Braven. Awoor closely resemble a hand’s anatomy: they have four “front” limbs, splayed out and used for grasping (two directly in the front and one on each side) with one powerful, rear leg that is used to propel them at high speeds. Their body is flat and shaped like a diamond. They have a mouth on their belly (with external teeth for latching) and a vent on their back (for expending vapor and smelling).

Bloodlusted

Passive: 20 Nature*

Analyze: 50 Nature

Awoor scream when they smell prey (within 40u or so) to notify sibling awoor of a possible feast.

Glutton for the Weak

Passive: 30 Nature or 50 Common

Analyze: 60 Nature

Awoor smell their targets. They prefer those that are afraid or fleeing, because of the adrenals.

Noxious

Passive: 40 Nature or 60 Alchemy

Analyze: 70 Nature

Dealing health damage to an awoor will release a noxious gas, choking nearby targets. It is best to use blunt damage when fighting awoor.

“Awoor - the word an insult but also a deeper reality. What does it mean to feed on the fearful?”

- Anonymous God, Shik-fal Scrolls

Behavior

Awoor often save their energy by sitting still, waiting until potential prey appears nearby. But once they find prey, they are are aggressive, reckless, and straightforward. Awoor do not regard their own lives as very important, and will never flee from a fight. Their drive to kill is social, so they are willing to sacrifice themselves if a sibling can have the chance to feed.

As awoor are blind and deaf, they rely solely on their sense of smell to navigate. It is believed that their smell is sensitive enough to tell distances, surface types, and many other small details.

Habitat and Life

Awoor live all over Braven but most commonly in caves and wooded areas that have a thriving wildlife population. They do favor areas that have seasonal rainfall, although why is unknown.

Awoor treat anything with blood as prey. As they feed they grow in size, eventually capable of spawning children of their own. But until that point awoor travel in sibling packs, with anywhere from two to a dozen total awoor in a pack.

Histories and Cultures

Legend goes that early in the first age a powerful sorcerer created the first awoor by severing their own hand in an experiment. The tale ends with the awoor eating its creator and spawning children.

Historical accounts note that awoor were a plague from the late first age until the middle of the second. Many believe the wyvern are to thank, as their numbers thinned greatly at this time.

Notes for Playing as

Awoor spread out and lie in wait - so they must be stumbled upon. Their lairs may contain treasure, but are likely just a pit of terror and death.

Enchanted by Water

Passive: 50 Nature & 50 Alchemy

Analyze: 100 Nature

Awoor are immobilized (stunned) when under running water or doused with water.

Weak to Submersion

Passive: 70 Nature & 70 Alchemy

Analyze: 120 Nature

If an awoor’s mouth & vapor vent are both submerged, the awoor pops, losing all Death Health.

Connected to Spawn

Passive: 80 Nature or 90 Essence

Analyze: 150 Nature

Nypmhs and adults have essence threads back to their spawner’s lair as long they live. Killing a spawner causes all its children to die within 7 days.

Awoor Nymph

Feed

12PT

Damage: [4d6+6 Health]

Info: Bite Attack (PU), 6 Base PT

Must be latched onto a target. This automatically hits latched location (no roll required). If target took stun in the last round, heal for half of damage done.

Leap and Latch

6PT

Leap at target within [8u] & attempt to latch onto a body part. Target may defend and use Struggle against your strength of [d100+50].

Scream2

10SN, Once per kill

Roll [d100+3d20+5] against all enemies in hearing range. Using Scream with another awoor only causes one roll to be made, but [+3d20] is added to the maneuver. If the roll exceeds any target’s [Courage Total + 50], that target takes [1d3 Stun]. This may be used once and then again for each killing blow you land.

~Passives~

Noxious Blood, Weak to Water

If you bleed or take health damage, all non-awoor targets within [2u] radius take [6d20 Stamina] and [1d6+2 Sanity] damage. Once per round.

Take [12 Stun] for every [1 Ration] of water that hits you. Explode if mouth and vent submerge.

Attack d100+80 (Bodily Attack)

Defense 130 (=PT, Dodge - can’t use if latched)

Awoor Spawner

Latch and Feed

21PT

Damage: [12d6+18 Health]

Info: Grab+Bite Attack (PU), 6 Base PT

Grab medium or smaller size target with front two legs. Target may defend and use Struggle against your strength of [d100+150]. If target is caught and does not escape, this may be used subsequently against them for only [12PT]. If target took stun in the last round, heal for half of damage done.

Sacrifice Spawn2

12PT, 10SN

Spray a thick tendril of spit onto a nearby awoor adult or nymph within [15u], paralyzing them and drawing them into your mouth. You heal for [10d20+900 Stamina] and [10d6 Health] to your lowest health limb (or Death health if all limbs are healed). When consumed, child’s noxious blood effect may trigger. If they had recently fed on a stunned target, this move refunds its Sanity cost.

~Passives~

Birthing Film, Noxious Blood

Immune to water weakness. Burst and spawn [1d6+2] Nymphs from belly on death or KO.

If you bleed or take health damage, all non-awoor targets within [10u] radius take [20d20 Stamina] and [3d6+6 Sanity] damage. Once per round.

Beguilers

Beguilers are huge cephalopods with a single, large eye in the center of their heads. Their appearance varies somewhat as they age - as chicks they look more squid-like with a longer, finned head. After they reach full maturity and breed, their fins are shed and their head grows rounder (and they grow smaller into late age). Their skin camoflauges to their environment and their singular eye has a powerful ability to entrance anything that looks into its gaze - creating illusions to seduce prey into euphoria.

Have a Blinded Watch

Passive: 40 Nature* or 40 Common

Analyze: 70 Nature

Keeping watch at night in pairs, with one wearing a blindfold is a classic trick used by sailors.

Stomachs in their Pads

Passive: 60 Nature

Analyze: 90 Nature

Every tentacle has its own stomach. Beguilers eat their prey alive, with their stomachs inside out.

Ammonia Stench

Passive: 70 Nature or 70 Alchemy

Analyze: 120 Nature

Recognizing the scent of ammonia can be a good sign that a beguiler has you under its spell. Knowing this grants +3d20 against their illusions.

“Beauty aloft beckons one to the brink, a nearly sexual euphoria... next come the tentacles.”

- Yis’rit Vautbaum, Theologies and Philosophies of Nature

Behavior

In youth and adulthood beguilers are active and powerful predators. They will seek out opportunities to deceive and consume prey. Old beguilers will lie in wait, expecting their prey to come to them.

Whether young or old, beguilers strike in darkness or low lighting - almost never in light. Wickedly intelligent and patient, beguilers strive to take their prey by surprise and will retreat if no one is deceived. Beguilers have been known to try to deceive ships at sea for several nights, slowly wearing down morale until the time is right.

Habitat and Life

Beguiler chicks need to feed weekly, adults monthly, and old beguilers only twice per year. Chicks and breeding-age beguilers live in deep waters and away from shores.

But after a beguiler has hatched children, they not only grow smaller but also much more passive as years strech on. The eldest beguilers leave the action of the seas in favor of lakes, watery ruins, caverns on a riverbed, and other waterbound places. They do this to catch more engaging prey.

Histories and Cultures

Obviously seafaring cultures speak at length about the dangers of beguilers - the main predator of those who travel by sea.

But some more esoteric tomes (like Vautbaum’s Theologies and Philosophies of Nature) explore the idea that beguilers’ sadistic intelligence goes far beyond their need for survival - noting their evil play is more “human” than even demons’.

Notes for Playing as

Think like a predator: take your time. Only fight if you absolutely must! You can always run away and try again at another time.

Blindfolds don’t Work

Passive: 80 Nature

Analyze: 150 Nature

Only those without eyes at all are immune to their magic - blindfolds are a sailor’s tale.

Be of Sound Spirits

Passive: 90 Nature & 90 Common

Analyze: 160 Nature

Having less than half of your Sanity remaining attracts Beguilers to you.

Vinegar... Stealth?

Passive: 100 Nature & 100 Alchemy

Analyze: 170 Nature

Covering yourself in vinegar can keep beguilers from smelling you or sensing your state of sanity. They can still hear and see you though!

Beguiler Chick

Digest

12PT

Damage: [24 Health + 3d100 Stamina]

Info: Acid Attack (BU), 6 Base PT

Vomit stomach & digest living, held target. No roll is made, automatically hits. If target’s Sanity is less than 50%, heal [2d6 Sanity] and [3d100 Stamina].

Ravish2

20SN, Once per turn

Give all targets with eyes within a [20u] radius euphoric hallucinations. Roll [d100+100] against each target’s [Willpower or Courage + 50] (whichever is higher). For every 10 points they fail, they take [1 Stun] but heal [1 Sanity]. This may be used up to twice per turn if every target takes stun.

Snatch2

6PT

Use a spare tentacle to grab target limb. Target may use a defense and Struggle against your strength of [d100+55]. This may be used defensively as a Catch with only Range negatives.

~Passives~

Hydrophillic, Incredible Reach, Wry

Can breathe water. Swim costs normal Move.

Attacks have +2 Melee Range.

Can breathe water. Swim costs normal Move.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +5 Melee Range and will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

9PT

Mass Paranoia

18PT & 50SN

All targets with eyes within a [10u] radius from you gain [2d100] to passive Perception against stealthed targets and every [1 Health] Damage dealt to them also deals [2 Sanity] Damage. Lasts 3 rounds. You are not affected by this ability.

Odium2

6PT, 15SN, & 3 Plot Points

Defense: Command target within [40u] to use their current attack on themselves or an ally within range of their attack. Target may resist, using their [Courage + 50] against your roll of [d100+300].

20SN, Once per turn

If you are more than [3u] above a target, they must use the lower value of their instead. For every 10 points they fail, they take [2 Stun] but heal [1 Sanity]. Snatch2

9PT & 30SN

Void of Will

Once per turn

Target in sight loses [300 Stamina] for every PT they spend. Lasts 3 rounds.

~Passives~

Abyssal Sight, Dynamic Marking/Wry, Hydrophillic, Impenetrable Mind, Size Advantage/Hellish Reach, Size Disadvantage, Vertical Mastery

Can see in complete darkness with no negatives, through walls, and the essence of targets. Only targets with hidden essence can sneak against you.

Any target touched can be tracked via smell for one year and you can know the Sanity of all targets. Doesn’t work for targets soaked in vinegar.

Can breathe water. Swim costs normal Move.

Immune to all social spells.

Huge: Attacks have +5 Melee Range.

Huge: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Small-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

Climbing costs normal Move. Can climb smooth surfaces, vertical and upside down and remain suspended using only 4 tentacles.

Casityr

The casityr is an enormous, quadrupedal monster of muscle, arguably the strongest living entity. They have the head of a lizard, crowned and bearded in spines with a long, thickly-scaled neck. Their eyes are black with piercing yellow if you meet their gaze (like a grenoren’s) and each eye can move independently. Their body has a musculature resembling a lion, covered in dense, short fur. Their enormous limbs are rippled with sinew. Each paw has fierce looking reddish-black claws with red smoke rising from them. They have two large tails, both covered in spines with what looks like a double-edged blade on the end.

Its Spines are Sharp

Passive: 80 Nature

Analyze: 110 Nature

Attacking this thing on the tail, neck, or head with melee attacks could be a bad idea.

And Eyes Sharper

Passive: 90 Nature

Analyze: 120 Nature

This keen creature has no blind spot and will know your level, stats, arts, defenses, abilities, and PT.

But Claws Sharpest.

Passive: 100 Nature or 90 Alchemy

Analyze: 150 Nature

The dark red of their claws has the same essence signature as the Red Poison. If they strike you, any death you face will be permanent and cursed.

“Red poison, ash, every corpse in ribbons; this happened 250 years back at Queets. Most curious.”

- Sha Stand, VNFC Period, Issue #488, the Complete Collection

Behavior

Casityr are incorrigible, aggressive, and violent and will leave nothing living once they begin a fight. They do not sleep and will pursue any that flee, killing each one by one until none live to tell about what happened to them.

Habitat and Life

Nothing is known about their habitat and life. So that being said, no known civilization or culture has recorded one - which is a sign that likely few have ever been near capital cities. They have no natural predators and can hold their own against just about anything.

Histories and Cultures

Some cultures and histories have noted that entire villages have been wiped out, with none left alive.

In other cases, legendary figures have been found absolutely mangled, with their whole party killed in the middle of a remote location.

These cases all note Red Poison as well as massive claw marks. But surely not all of these cases are due to a casityr attack?

Notes for Playing as

In consistency with Braven lore, you will only ever deploy the casityr when your players have angered an extremely powerful god-like figure (something on par with max demons or dragons). If you do this, know that the casityr act like the thugs of the ultimate, cosmic mafia: they are sent to completely destroy something and leave absolutely none alive. The casityr can talk, but it rarely has anything to say (best not to anyway).

When a casityr dies or completes its mission - it will both evaporate and turn to ash, leaving almost nothing behind.

It is Unnatural

Passive: 120 Nature* & 120 Essence

Analyze: 190 Nature

This beast isn’t of this world or plane. Spells portaled or whispered will have a hard time.

And was Formed

Passive: 140 Nature or 140 Alchemy

Analyze: 210 Nature

This monstrosity was created using illegal, pithological runes. It is immune to wounds and insanity.

For a Purpose.

Passive: 160 Nature or 160 Essence

Analyze: 230 Nature

Something incredibly powerful created this super assassin and doesn’t want anyone to know. It has no essence or essence thread.

Level 95

+15 Plot Points

Languages

Demonic (3) & Old Nia (3)

Size: Immense

Occupies: 5x11x7 (5u wide, 11u long, 7u tall)

Free once per turn (may also trigger)

Damage: [50 Health + 6d20+1000 Stamina]x3

Info: Missile Attack (PU+SL), 6 Base PT

Use again each time your Head/Neck/Tails are hit.

Swipe

15PT

Damage: [80 Health + 6d20+4000 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (CH+BU+SL), 6 Base PT

Any target hit by this move is cursed with the Red Poison. See the Green Book for more.

~Passives~

Berserk, Gory, Perfect Insight, No Trace, Size Advantage/Disadvantage

No negatives are applied if wounded or insane.

Triple Trauma Effects, Crit on a roll of 76-100. Restore [5PT] if you deal a Wound to a target.

Can see 360 degrees. Know all targets’ MIT, Stats, Arts, Vitality, Move, Evade, PT, Gifts, and Level.

Turn to essenceless ash and vapor upon death.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +2 Melee Range and will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

Deathless

Deathless are a well-documented phenomenon that haunt many areas of the world. Deathless are animated bones, essentially (pun intended). No really, an environmental essence field will bring bones to life in order to defend itself, like an immune response to unwanted visitations. Deathless can take many forms visually, but are always some variation of humanoid or quadrupedal beast, typically well past death (to the point where they are skeletons in rags with rusted weapons).

They can’t be “killed”

Passive: 20 Essence*

Analyze: 50 Essence

They reanimate after some unknown amount of time, and cannot lose Death Health or bleed.

They are mindless

Passive: 30 Essence or 50 Common

Analyze: 60 Essence

They are immune to all social maneuvers and social spells. They cannot lose Sanity.

Liminal Limit

Passive: 40 Essence or 60 Nature

Analyze: 70 Essence

The bones won’t choose to leave a certain radius, for some reason. If forced out, they lose animation and “die” (unless placed back in).

“The theological divide on Deathless: ‘God is not here,’ in the east and ‘Encounter god’ in the west.”

- Yis’rit Vautbaum, Theologies and Philosophies of Nature

Behavior

Deathless may not be visibly apparent in an environment at first, as it is possible they are simply buried corpses, strewn about an old battlefield.

Deathless are slow, but unwavering. They don’t move and emote in the same way a living thing would - they are uncanny and often hauntingly animated. Their slightly-off movements can be jarring, but their ultimate goal is to either kill or fend off any unwanted visitors. If they do manage to kill, that will be future bones to be used for defense, so the more the merrier.

Habitat and Life

Deathless can be found all across Braven, even in cities and underwater. Deathless do not eat, drink, or sleep. They obviously do not reproduce and have no individual motivations. The environment itself is the source of each Deathless’ will to act.

Histories and Cultures

Since many battlefields and graveyards throughout the ages have become vindictive environments, it is no wonder that plenty of cultures have spoken of these dangerous, unholy places.

While the animated figures are called “Deathless” the Holy Body refers to these environments as “Godless,” noting that “If God were here, then this abomination would not stand.” This is why Templar and Paladins seek to purge undeath.

However, some religions regard these areas as sacred, that nature preceeds and supercedes humanity. Undeath shows mortals their insignificance.

Notes for Playing as

Build the tension: show evidence of bones strewn about and give a backstory for the angry place. Deathless should be “solved” by narratively putting a Godless to rest. The fight is secondary.

If the bones are white...

Passive: 50 Essence & 50 Alchemy

Analyze: 100 Essence

“...adventurer’s delight.” White-boned deathless take double stun and 30 minutes to reanimate.

If the bones are red...

Passive: 60 Essence & 60 Alchemy

Analyze: 110 Essence

“...adventurer’s dread.” Red-boned can spread the Red Poison and reanimate within 1 minute.

Liminal Lacuna

Passive: 70 Essence or 90 Nature

Analyze: 140 Essence

The “cause” of deathless is an angry environment’s essence. Perhaps if it can be soothed (or destroyed), the deathless will cease forever at this location.

Deathless Ranger

Basic Attack

8PT, 1 Ammo

Damage: [10 Health + 3d20+75 Stamina]

Info: 2H Bow (PU), 30u Range, 5 Base PT

Recouperate2

6PT

Stand still and heal [160 Stamina].

Quick-shot

20Stam, Once per turn

+[2PT] to use toward a Missile/Thrown attack.

~Passives~

Deathless, Loose Limbs, Stun-prone

Does not use breath, cannot take Death Health or Sanity damage, immune to all social maneuvers and social spells, cannot be wounded. If Stamina reaches 0, will reanimate in 30min at full Stamina.

If a limb reaches 0 health, it will fall off. During reanimation, limbs crawl back and reattach. May also grab limb and reattach for 6PT.

Stun effects received are doubled.

2nd Wind I, Deathless, Loose Limbs, Stun-prone

Once per day when Stamina reaches below 425, heal [14d20+280 Stamina].

Does not use breath, cannot take Death Health or Sanity damage, immune to all social maneuvers and social spells, cannot be wounded. If Stamina reaches 0, will reanimate in 30min at full Stamina.

If a limb reaches 0 health, it will fall off. During reanimation, limbs crawl back and reattach. May also grab limb and reattach for 6PT.

Stun effects received are doubled.

2nd Wind I, Animated Limbs, Brawn/Violent, Deathless, Size Advantage/Long Reach, Size Disadvantage

Once per day when Stamina reaches below 3450, heal [30d20+600 Stamina].

If a limb reaches 0 health, it will fall off and spawn as a white boned Deathless. If the main mass reaches 0 health, your Stamina lowers to 0 but you spawn 1d6+2 white bone and 1 red bone.

Double Trauma effects.

Does not use breath, cannot take Death Health or Sanity damage, immune to all social maneuvers and social spells, cannot be wounded. If ten or more deathless of any kind are reanimating, instead you may instantly reanimate.

Hitting legs removes 1 Move Counter from foe.

Huge: Attacks have +2 Melee Range.

~Passives~

Chosen Deathless, Death Master, Dev/Asc, Hold/Good T/Obsv, Phylacterous, Moxie, Strategization

Does not use breath, cannot take Death Health damage and cannot be wounded. If Sanity reaches 0, you die. If Stamina reaches 0, will reanimate in 1min at full Stamina.

All corpses within 80u are animated and obey your will in addition to any Deathless.

If target Lore Type is Essence or Common: Damaging spells deal double Trauma Points. Non damage spells automatically succeed on a roll of 86-100.

Know INI order. May hold turn. Can interrupt others to begin turn (if held).

Soul Essence split among phylacteries. Will die if essence is unbound from all of them.

May use Spell Resist against Social Spells.

Gain +2d20 counter to use on any maneuver for each turn that begins before yours.

If a limb reaches 0 health, it will fall off. During reanimation, limbs crawl back and reattach. May also grab limb and reattach for 6PT.

Wits 55

Awareness 115

Craftiness 90

Inscription 105

Tactics 90

Prestige 45

Authority 75

Charisma 65

Nerve 30

Courage 60

Willpower 90

Demons

Demons are immediately terrifying, just in their aura alone. From the tiny che’hekk to the croatoas, they can have a variety of adornments (or not) from ragged sackcloth, to armor, to pure nudity. Che’hekk have wings and are about the size of a child’s toy doll or a pint of ale, just a touch larger than a fairy. Che’hekk are often naked. Their skin is typically very pale, almost transluscent white. Pixies’ wings stopped growing in exchange for tiny horns. They stand just a head shorter than a halfling, often dressed in rags. Imps are generally between a dwarf or hume in height but rarely as emaciated as a pixie and often wearing regular clothes and armor. Imps and all demons greater often tattoo and stain their pale-white skin with a single bright color in thick, geometric patterns. Their horns and size only grow larger with age and more power, in addition to gaining more relics, tools, weapons, and armor.

They make deals

Passive: 20 Essence*

Analyze: 50 Essence

Everyone and their mom knows that demons deal in things, right? Surely they can be reasoned with.

Not so reasonable...

Passive: 30 Essence or 40 Common

Analyze: 60 Essence

The winged gnat demons, pixies, and imps all just seem berserk. Perhaps only powerful ones deal.

You can feel them near

Passive: 40 Essence or 70 Awareness

Analyze: 70 Essence

Demonic presence has a haunting and memorable gravity to it. Recognizing this, one can learn to feel their presence within 20 units.

Imps have Bosses

Passive: 50 Essence or 70 Common

Analyze: 80 Essence

Imps and greater are “legit” demons - they signed the paperwork and work for an organized syndicate. They are obligated to respect the hierarchy.

Summon = Deal

Passive: 60 Essence

Analyze: 90 Essence

If a demon can be found, it isn’t the sort you make a deal with. Fiends and greater demons can only be summoned (through spells or word of mouth).

They want Blood

Passive: 70 Essence

Analyze: 100 Essence

Humanity’s essence transported through blood is the currency of the demonic economy - whether in small portions or all at once.

Beware Bloodletters

Passive: 90 Essence & 90 Alchemy

Analyze: 140 Essence (other target)

Some bind themselves to demonic pacts through regular bloodletting “payments.” Devices that do this such as blood bracers can be a warning sign.

They are Born of Fay

Passive: 110 Essence & 110 Nature

Analyze: 160 Essence

Che-hekk are fay that are seduced into betraying the Fayfolk by the notion of “individuality over mutuality” (or serving your own interests first).

Full Moon Salvation

Passive: 130 Essence & 130 Nature

Analyze: 180 Essence

Demons can possess you once they taste your blood. However like Fay, their link to you clears the moment a full moon rises. This means full moon nights are when demons begin their prowl.

3 Different Contracts

Passive: 150 Essence

Analyze: 220 Essence

Demonic contracts work in one of three ways: A singular exchange of blood for something powerful, a “microcurse” which automatically pays due any time you use the power the demon granted, or an “insurance” contract that one pays into in hopes that it eventually will pay off.

5 Different Syndicates

Passive: 170 Essence

Analyze: 240 Essence

Demons dye their skin to mark where they belong.Red, Green, Blue, Black, and White. They seem to share laws but compete with each other. White and Black are the greater syndicates, while the other three seem to be lesser.

“Ageless antagonists with devious plots. They are the perfect villains - a celestial mafia of blood.”

- E.R. Dyan, The Cosmic Drama: Demons, Dragons, Dieties

Behavior

There is a spectrum of behavior common to demons: the weaker and less experienced are marked by rebellious violence and blood lust. As demons grow, they gain confidence and coolheadedness. They seem even capable of coexisting with humans (if of course they didn’t prey on them).

Che’hekk and pixies are generally considered terrors all across Braven for being cruel, muderous little wretches. They break into homes at night and steal children, attack wayfarers who travel alone, or find any other means to exploit the vulnerable. They are a constant blight.

Imps appear almost like young adult humans in that they are both a bit rebellious but also clearly dependent on structure and order guiding their lives. They are learning to be obedient to their masters, and eager to prove their worth. They are the first line of enforcement in a syndicate.

Fiends are bold, courageous, and aggressive - but not without deep regard for the rules of engagement. They clearly seek to exploit the work of others beneath them so that their masters will approve of them and give them a cut of the gain.

Croatoas are the bourgeoisie of demons - they enjoy incredible profits, loyalty, and a life of significant leisure. Clever, litigious, and always down to exploit others (often through aggressive pursuit of contract fulfilment), they rarely directly intervene or answer any summons personally. All activity in an arm of a syndicate is governed by a croatoas. They treat fiends as their military and police commanders, with imps as their troops or enforcers - out to make sure that every contract is paid and no breach goes unpunished.

Habitat and Life

Demons can be found in many places, but in general anywhere that humans have hierarchy you can expect demons to be there too. While rural towns might be plagued more by che’hekks and pixies, any society of size has a significant demon underground (sometimes literally).

Imps, pixies, and che’hekks interact often with humans, but typically on violent terms (they are after something). Due to their physical intervention in human life, their dwellings can be tracked and sought out.

Fiends and croatoas are not easy to find. Where they dwell is unknown and many speculate they don’t even live on the same plane of existence.

Histories and Cultures

Understandably, the greatest villain of humanity has been demonic forces since before histories were even recorded. Whether or not demons learned to order their society first and humans followed suit or vice versa has been a debate among scholars for millennia.

Every culture with a written or oral history notes something of che’hekks, pixies, and imps in one form of another. A few fail to mention fiends or croatoas at all, most suspiciously.

Fayfolk and the fay have the oldest recorded histories documenting demonkind, while the Holy Body has the most in-depth scholarship (almost scientific knowledge).

Both fayfolk and the Holy Body are constantly at odds with demonkind, fighting on many fronts. Whether defending rural town borders, protecting poor fools who made bad deals, or uncovering secret plots to overthrow society - the fayfolk and the Holy Body are always hunting demons.

Notes for Playing as

Demons can randomly attack at low levels, simply looking to feast on blood. But as your party grows in level, their encounters with demons should rarely ever be random. Demons are extremely careful.

Try to build a “celestial mafia” with different levels of power. High level demons will almost never answer summons directly and certainly would only ever seek out a character if they had more than proven themselves first.

Your characters at level 20 won’t be interesting to a Croatoas, but they might intrigue the local Fiend looking to work an angle on the town mayor or blackmail the police chief. Get creative and just imagine what sort of world an exploitative underground of turf-insecure predators would build.

Che’hekk, Petty Demon

Level 3

Languages

Demonic (2) & Fay (3)

Size: Tiny

Occupies: Less than 1x1x1

Attack d100+35 (Bodily Attack)

Move 3/2 INI 11 PT 8

Stam 330 SN 35 DH 20

Head

MIT 0 | 0%

Evade +50

Health 1

Rest of Body

MIT 0 | 0%

Evade +30

Health 14

Gnash

4PT

Damage: [8 Health + 2d20+20 Stamina]

Info: Bite Attack (PU), 4 Base PT

Effect: If you dealt health damage, gain 1 Possession Charge against target.

Possess

8PT & 5SN, Opt: 1 Possession Charge

A pure white thread of your essence reaches out and touches target within [20u]. Target loses [1d20 Sanity]. This move cannot be defended against.

Optional: If you spend at least 1 Possession Charge, you may control [1 PT] of your target’s actions each turn for every [5 points] their current Sanity is below 0. Actions you take while you possess them use their ZQ, WL, GR, and PR arts but your ER, WT, PS, and NV arts and your Sanity’s current state.

This lasts for 1 Round per Possession Charge spent or until target’s Sanity recovers. This optional Possession effect may be defended against using target’s [Courage or Willpower + 50] (whichever is lower) against your [d100+25]. (If multiple demons attempt to posses the target at the same time, the highest value gets to use target’s PT first.)

Can use Move in any direction and hold mid-air.

Info: 2H Bow (PU), 25u Range, 4x2 Base PT

Effect: Targets center of body. All arrows deal full damage but land randomly (using Glance table).

Possess

8PT & 15SN, Opt: 1 Possession Charge

A pure white thread of your essence reaches out and touches target within [40u]. Target loses [3d20 Sanity]. This move cannot be defended against.

Optional: If you spend at least 1 Possession Charge, you may control [3 PT] of your target’s actions each turn for every [5 points] their current Sanity is below 0. Actions you take while you possess them use their ZQ, WL, GR, and PR arts but your ER, WT, PS, and NV arts and your Sanity’s current state.

This lasts for 1 Round per Possession Charge spent or until target’s Sanity recovers. This optional Possession effect may be defended against using target’s [Courage or Willpower + 50] (whichever is lower) against your [d100+75]. (If multiple demons attempt to posses the target at the same time, the highest value gets to use target’s PT first.)

~Passives~

All non-demons within [30u] lose [2SN] per round. Does not stack with other Dread auras.

8PT & 30SN, Opt: 1 Possession Charge

An invisible thread of your essence reaches out and touches target in sight. Target loses [6d20 Sanity]. This move cannot be defended against.

Optional: If you spend at least 1 Possession Charge, you may control [1 PT] of your target’s actions each turn for every [6 points] of Sanity Damage you have dealt to them since last using a Possession Charge.

When you possess the target, they take on your physical form until the possession ends. Actions you or the target take while you possess them use all of your Stats, Arts, and State. You are able to use all of your abilities and theirs, but they are only able to use their own abilities.

This lasts for 1 Round per Possession Charge spent or until your Stamina, Sanity, or Death Health reach 0. This optional Possession effect may be defended against using target’s [Courage or Willpower + 50] (whichever is lower) against your [d100+145]. Willpower 300

Dragons

Dragons are winged, quadrupedal beasts of enormous size that grow larger and more powerful with age. Dragons are covered in thick scales, with sharp claws, opposable thumbs, a long tail, and piercing golden eyes with vertical pupils. The males have beards while the females have horns. At a young age, males begin with only whiskers on their chin and under their nostrils, but grow longer and thicker as they age. Females begin with small horns that grow larger and more practical as they mature. All dragons are born colored on a spectrum between dark green and dark brown. However, dragons are a vane creature and will decorate themselves in paints, jewelry, and even loose fabrics in the form of large scarves. Dragon aesthetics change across the years with new trends in “fashion,” but generally they will cover their entire bodies in a single, solid color - whatever is their favorite.

Dangerous Breath

Passive: 20 Nature*

Analyze: 50 Nature

A dragon’s fiery spit burns hotter and longer than normal fire and is thick like tar.

Hoard Wealth

Passive: 30 Nature or 40 Common

Analyze: 60 Nature

Dragons collect many things over the years, by gift or conquest. Their lairs are famously full.

Love Flattery, Gifts

Passive: 40 Nature or 60 Common

Analyze: 70 Nature

Prideful dragons may spare an adventurer’s life if they receive gifts or worship. They especially love dragon-sized jewelry, scarves, and body paint.

Territorial

Passive: 50 Nature

Analyze: 80 Nature

Dragons spread their eggs out in their lair so that when they are born, the children don’t immediately kill one another. In life, dragons fight for turf but often become more congenial with age.

Hate Golemics

Passive: 60 Nature or 80 Alchemy

Analyze: 90 Nature

Dragons absolutely despise golems and golemic magic. Dragons thwart golemancy at all costs.

Respect Narks

Passive: 70 Nature

Analyze: 100 Nature

Dragons do everything in their power to respect and protect nark adders and gullings. Dragons will even go out of their way to help narks in need.

Bonds of Stone

Passive: 90 Nature and 90 Alchemy

Analyze: 140 Nature

The stone walls of a dragon’s lair telepathically notify the dragon of trespass (even if they are asleep) and may contain their dreams and memories.

Particular Personas

Passive: 110 Nature or 130 Common

Analyze: 160 Nature

There are 3 kinds of dragons: slothful (depressed), wrathful (violent), and prideful (arrogant). You can now identify which is which immediately.

Beware Nark Migration

Passive: 130 Nature

Analyze: 180 Nature (other targets)

If you notice nark gullings or adders fleeing an area in large numbers, this could mean a dragon notified them they plan to attack a locale. Dragons will do this to protect wyvern brood.

Mental Succession

Passive: 150 Nature & 150 Common

Analyze: 220 Nature

Dragons pass their memories to their children, which means all dragons carry memory of the Great Trauma. Most dragons, especially younger ones, hate humanity for this and are wrathful and wish to destroy. Some dragons instead seek to dominate and be worshipped by humanity and are prideful. Even fewer dragons have forgiven the crimes of the past, but these spend most of their time deep in thought, depressed and conflicted.

Cosmic

Passive: 170 Nature & 150 Essence

Analyze: 240 Nature

Dragons can command virtually every fauna of Braven and even nullify Godless.

“After the Great Trauma, who can blame dragons for hating us? They never forget - never.”

- E.R. Dyan, The Cosmic Drama: Demons, Dragons, Dieties

Behavior

Dragons are notably more aggressive in the first few stages of life, and some dragons are just predisposed to violence. However, the oldest dragons are notably only either prideful or slothful, and not so full of wrath. This is perhaps theorized because the violent dragons meet their end before they can live a long life.

The “3 Personas” are how scholars refer to the dominant personalities that dragons possess. While some stipulate that a dragon is born with one persona for life, others look at the most famous dragons as notable outliers to that idea. Either way, dragons are discussed in terms of Wrathful (will assault human cities and settlements), Prideful (will convince a populace or people to worship them), or Slothful (will spend their life in thoughtful isolation and inaction).

Female dragons are more protective of their lair and less trusting of others who draw near. (It is surmised that their horns are used to fend off intruders from reaching their eggs or even test a would-be male breeder of their worthiness.)

Male dragons on the other hand often suffer from anxiety and can even be transient their entire lives - never settling on a domain for long.

Habitat and Life

Dragons live surrounded by stone, which is believed to enhance their dreams and memories. Dragon’s lairs often cause a delirious experience for visitors, the stones can create visions and hallucinations that are bewildering or horrific. It is generally believed that the visions merely reflect whatever the dragon’s latest dreams entailed.

The stones of a dragon’s lair will lose their powers if removed from their context. There is something about the stone at the location itself that is important to the phenomenon. When a dragon dies, the stones do not cease. Only if a new dragon arrives do the stones change.

In life, dragons will seek out prey actively during their waking period but are asleep otherwise.

It is also during this time that male dragons will seek out a female’s lair. Females lay their eggs all throughout their lair in anticipation that a suitable male will fertilize them. Males do not stay with the mother of their children, and will often immediately leave after fertilizing as many eggs as they can find. For this reason, females will often only lay a few eggs at a time so that their brood can have a variety of different fathers with different memories. Females generally reject a male who returns to fertilize again.

The time when dragons are most miserable is during their incubation period until a few days after they’ve been born. It is during this time that their mind is growing and maturing and they are processing all of the memories of their ancestors. (It is theorized that the incubation of dragons has grown longer and longer through the years because each new generation has more memories to sift through.) In addition to the misery of their inheritance, dragons know that after they are born they may have to kill their siblings to live.

Histories and Cultures

Dragons have played interesting roles throughout history, but of course the first records of humanity all begin with a description of the same event (but from different perspectives): the Great Trauma, or the Culling of the Dragons.

Long ago, the Mirthics of the First Moon created golems, gargoyles, and titans to hunt down and kill every living dragon in Braven. A mysterious weapon used in the mirthics’ civil war destroyed their moon and killed them all. This ended the persecution of the dragons. Only a few survived.

History notes occasional draconic cults, battles between dragons and demons, and even dragons intervening in human affairs. From works of fiction to offical records, the majesty and terror of dragons are never an overspent subject.

Notes for Playing as

Think in terms of the 3 Personas, but give even the violent dragons a good backstory and motivation. Wrathful dragons are not stupid beasts, and they all should be regarded as real characters with carefully crafted strategies. Note that rarely (if ever) should wrathful dragons exist beyond Mature age - they really don’t live that long.

Dragon Wyrm

Level 20

+5 Plot Points

Languages

Stone (1) & All other Languages (3)

Size: Large

Occupies: 2x4x2 (2u wide, 4u long, 2u tall).

Hew

9PT & 5SN

Damage: [30 Health + 6d20+400 Stamina]

Info: Claw Attack (CH + SL), 6 Base PT

Shred

Opportunity, May trigger 1x/Turn

Damage: [4d6+4 Health + 3d20+200 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (SL or IM), 6 Base PT

Effects: Use tail, teeth, or horns to attack a target that moves into, moves out of, or remains in melee range (at the end of their turn).

Spew

9PT & 500 Stamina, Must recharge

Damage: [6d20 Health + 4d100+400 Stamina]

Info: Breath Attack (BU + DI), 6 Base PT

Effects: Spit flaming, molten slag in a [1u] wide and [1d3+3u] long column anywhere within a [20u] range. Attack hits entire units, placing randomly (using the glance table) as if it were an Immense attack.

Targets hit are covered in slagfire and take the damage of the attack again each round at half damage for [1d2] Rounds. If no target was hit, the unit itself is covered in slagfire and will deal full damage (placed randomly) to anything that enters the unit until the duration ends. Slagfire cannot be put out with water or wind.

This move takes [1d3+1] Rounds to recharge or may recharge instantly for [5 Plot Points].

Squall2

9PT, 100Stam

Surge both wings forward. All targets within [3u] range in a [3u] wide swathe in front of you take [1d6] Knockback and must roll Balance against a DC of [95] or be knocked down.

~Passives~

Astute, Lrg. than Life/Molten, Omniglot/Sublime Sway, Sinister, Winged

Know all targets’ MIT, Stats, Arts, Vitality, Move, Evade, PT, gifts, and level.

Receive 50% Stun, Bleeding, and Fire Damage.

May speak and listen to anything with full proficiency (from flora & fauna, to the living & dead). Can use Prestige maneuvers on all sentient things.

Crit on a roll of 86-100.

Can use Move in any direction and hold mid-air.

Surge both wings forward. All targets within [6u] range in a [6u] wide swathe in front of you take [2d6] Knockback and must roll Balance against a DC of [125] or be knocked down.

Astute, Fastidious, Lrg. than Life/Molten, Omniglot/Sublime Sway, Size Advantage, Size Disadvantage, Winged

Know all targets’ MIT, Stats, Arts, Vitality, Move, Evade, PT, gifts, and level.

Crit on a roll of 76-100.

Receive 50% Stun, Bleeding, and Fire Damage.

May speak and listen to anything with full proficiency (from flora & fauna, to the living & dead). Can use Prestige maneuvers on all sentient things.

Huge: Attacks have +1 Melee Range.

Huge: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Small-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost much more PT.

Can use Move in any direction and hold mid-air.

Hew

15PT & 10SN

Info: Claw Attack (CH + SL), 6 Base PT

Bleeding effects doubled.

Shred

Opportunity, May trigger 3x/Turn

Damage: [4d6+20 Health + 3d20+700 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (SL or IM), 6 Base PT

Effects: Use tail, teeth, or horns to attack a target that moves into, moves out of, or remains in melee range (at the end of their turn).

Spew

15PT & 800 Stamina, Must recharge

Damage: [12d20 Health + 4d100+1400 Stamina]

Info: Breath Attack (BU + BU + DI), 6 Base PT

Effects: Spit flaming, molten slag in a [2u] wide and [1d6+4u] long column anywhere within a [40u] range. Attack hits entire units, placing randomly (using the glance table).

Targets hit are covered in slagfire and take the damage of the attack again each round at half damage for [1d3+1] Rounds. During this additional time, body part loses [5|500] MIT. If no target was hit, the unit itself is covered in slagfire and will deal full damage (placed randomly) to anything that enters the unit until the duration ends. Slagfire cannot be put out with water or wind.

This move takes [1d3] Rounds to recharge or may recharge instantly for [5 Plot Points].

May speak and listen to anything with full proficiency (from flora & fauna, to the living & dead). Can use Prestige maneuvers on all sentient things.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +2 Melee Range and will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

Entozunes

Entozunes are massive, red sandworms with no eyes and a round mouth completely filled with sharp, triangular teeth. Their bodies have ringed sections and are sausage-like in shape (they are round, smooth, and thick relative to their overall length). Their heads are covered collection of diamond shaped plates. When they spit it sounds like an aggressive hiss and as they bite they make a shrill, whistling growl, because they suck air in swiftly over their teeth (to help hold their prey).

Spot the Burrow

Passive: 20 Nature* or 60 Awareness

Analyze: 50 Nature

Entozune burrow in a “U” shape, to lure their prey. Once you know this, it is easy to spot them.

Dangerous Spit

Passive: 30 Nature & 30 Alchemy

Analyze: 60 Nature

Entozune like to digest soft foods, so their spit turns hard things pillowy.

Stay on the Stones

Passive: 40 Nature or 60 Common

Analyze: 70 Nature

Sandstone roads were built through deserts because Entozune cannot detect movement on stone. Stay on rocks or roads whenever possible.

“Spitting, writhing, gluttonous red worms... beloved in fiction but utterly despised in reality.”

- Eoghan Scrivener, On Creatures

Behavior

Unlike their primary prey, nabinasks (also a desert predator), entozunes are fairly inactive. They will move only to find a new waiting spot.

They are an aggressive and territorial predator for this reason, so they are rarely encountered in numbers. But that being said, if entozunes are disputing turf when prey appears, they will prioritize the prey first.

Both grubs and grown entozunes are not particularly clever or intelligent, and they are known to give up if their prey is not easy to sense.

Habitat and Life

Entozunes live in the soft sands of the southern deserts and even as far as the Bush and Setrocania. However, it is recorded in Orcish history that the deserts of the Distant Lands beyond the Deep also had entozunes.

Entozunes asexually lay eggs underground and they incubate for about 60 days until they hatch. Young grubs stay with their parent for around a decade until leaving to find their own turf.

Histories and Cultures

Every traveller of the deserts has heard of entozunes in some form or another. As much pop writing in the nations of the south focuses on the “grabbers of the sands” as the infamous, anti-authoritarian communalists of the Roost.

But some of the oldest known written records in Braven come from the pre-Kaldaki texts, which describe the “ento zhoonloi” as the third ancient wyrm, after the wyvern and wiwil.

Notes for Playing as

If players aren’t travelling on stone: strike! Set up a trap or (if you want to get crazy) a scene with nabinasks, to have a three way fight.

Force Regurgitation

Passive: 50 Nature

Analyze: 100 Nature

Causing a loud sound or explosion in or near an entozune’s head will cause them to retract their teeth and vomit all recently consumed prey.

Avoid wearing Yellow

Passive: 60 Nature

Analyze: 110 Nature

Entozunes attack and eat yellow targets first.

Special Enzymes

Passive: 70 Nature & 70 Alchemy

Analyze: 120 Nature

The digestive enymes of an entozune can be preserved with an equal amount of salt. The enzymes are incredibly helpful against nabinasks.

Entozune Worm

Bite and Chew

9PT

Damage: [d6+14 Health + 3d20+80 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (ML), UB, 6 Base PT

Deals double damage if you have already bitten the target and they have not caused you to let go. Target may use Struggle to force you to let go. A loud noise that causes Intimidation with a roll greater than [75] will also cause you to let go.

Burrow/Unburrow

3 uses of Move

Burrow: If sand is directly below your head, you may burrow into the ground. While burrowed, your MIT rises by [20|60%] and Stealth by [d100]. You may use burrow again to go deeper and become completely untargetable and untrackable (except via spells), but you must use Unburrow twice to surface instead of just once.

Unburrow: As long as only sand is above you, you may rise towards the surface. Unburrow must be used an equal number of times as Burrow was used in order to rise to the surface.

Spit

9PT, 25Stam, & 5SN

Deal [1d20] DUR damage to any armor on target limb within a [15u] range in front of you. Limb loses all MIT gained from Hard armor (metal, wood, stone, carapace, etc) for 2 Rounds.

~Passives~

Predatory, Sandsense, Sandswimmer

Gain +10 to hit if attacking before your target (via Stealth or Initiative order).

Blind but can detect within [500u] through sand.

Can move inside sand with no disadvantages.

Attack d100+60 (Missile/Bodily Attack)

Defense 110 (=PT, Dodge)

Entozune

Level 30

+4 Plot Points

Languages

Sand (3) & Therion (3)

Size: Medium

Occupies: 3x40x3 (3u wide, 40u long, 3u tall).

Burrow/Unburrow2

1 use of Move (3 if used out of turn)

Burrow: If sand is directly below your head, you may burrow into the ground. While burrowed, your MIT rises by [20|60%] and Stealth by [d100]. You may use burrow again to go deeper and become completely untargetable and untrackable (except via spells), but you must use Unburrow twice to surface instead of just once.

Unburrow: As long as only sand is above you, you may rise towards the surface. Unburrow must be used an equal number of times as Burrow was used in order to rise to the surface. You have a diameter of [5u], so unburrowing will cause [1d3+1] Knockback to all units in a [2u] radius from the center of your Unburrow. If there is a target directly in the center of your unburrowing, you may optionally use Consume on them for [9PT] and [30SN] as an attempted Sneak Attack.

Devour

18PT or 4 Plot Points

Damage: [2d6+28 Health + 3d20+600 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (CH+ML), 6 Base PT

Ingest Large (or smaller) sized target completely. Target takes the damage from this attack every round they remain in your belly (places randomly). You may use Devour on a new target once every other round and on a maximum of 6 targets total (before requiring 1 month digestion). Loud noises that cause Intimidation with a roll greater than [120] will cause you to vomit up the most recent prey you devoured that is still in your belly.

Spit

18PT & 100Stam or 2 Plot Points

Deal [1d20] DUR damage to all armor on target unit within a [30u] range in front of you. Armor loses all MIT gained from Hard armor (metal, wood, stone, carapace, etc) for 2 Rounds.

Opportunity: Can be used as an Opportunity if target moves within [10u] or out of melee range or if you Unburrow and a target is within [10u].

Attack (Roll only for Chance to Crit)

Defense (See Burrow/Unburrow)

S. Resist 135, Lore Type: Nature

Move 12/7 INI 20 PT 25

Stam 3400 SN 120, +1 DH 225

Head

MIT 15 | 40%

Evade -50

Health 400

Body

MIT 4 | 60%

Evade -50

Health 1200

~Passives~

Brawn, First Move, Predatory, Sandswimmer, Sinister, Size Advantage, Size Disadvantage, Spiteful, Surgical

Double Trauma effects.

1 Free Move to use at the beginning of combat.

Gain +10 to hit if attacking before your target (via Stealth or Initiative order).

Blind but can detect within [1500u] through sand.

Can move inside sand with no disadvantages.

Crit on a roll of 86-100.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +2 Melee Range and will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

2 Opportunities per turn, heal [300 Stamina] and remove [1d6+1 Bleeding] if an Opportunity hits.

Add [+4d6 Health] damage per Trauma Level.

Physique 100

Arm Muscle 150

Leg Muscle 150

Wits 20

Craftiness 20

Inscription 20

Tactics 60

Prestige 10

Authority 10

Charisma 10

Nerve 45

Courage 70

Willpower 80

Fay

Fay have a variety of appearances. Wisps are tiny, wingless, gender-neutral humanoids that stand no taller than a pint of ale. They wear leaves and grass woven as clothing. Their skin colors are soft pastel hues from pinks, to greens, to blues. A fairy is simply a wisp that has grown wings (and matured). Sprites vary in size between a halfkin to a hume and are covered in short red, brown, or black fur. They closely resemble a squirrel, with large, curved, bushy tails, small, bright black eyes, button noses, and upright ears with pointed fur at the tips. Sylph are between a halfkin and dwarf in height with the legs and horns of a goat and the upper body of any variety of humanoid. Kelpie are horse-sized and have a horse-like head, with fins instead of hair, a horse-like neck and shoulders, muscular, large arms with humanoid hands, and a horizontal, fish-like lower body with two large fins side-by side. Kelpie have smooth, shiny skin that is green, blue, purple, or red mottled with white spots of varying sizes. Middron are huge, horned beasts with red eyes, the head and legs of a bull, and hairy, thick, masculine, chest and arms.

They Haunt Traumas

Passive: 20 Essence or 50 Common

Analyze: 50 Essence

Fay are to beings what Godless are to the earth. Sites where suffering or trauma is committed against the living or dead can spawn fay.

Slow to Trust

Passive: 30 Essence

Analyze: 60 Essence

Most fay are friendly but slow to trust.

Smell of Peat

Passive: 40 Essence* or 50 Nature

Analyze: 70 Essence

A strong smell of peat could mean fay is near.

Bond-o-the-wisp

Passive: 50 Essence or 80 Common

Analyze: 80 Essence

Wisps and fairies have been known to create deep bonds with some people, even for life. Note: they are not pets, but their own individuals.

Charity and Harmony

Passive: 60 Essence

Analyze: 90 Essence

A sprite begging or being put to sleep by sylphsong can be a blessing. If you and your comrades have a harmonious, wholesome relationship, these fay will reward you with random treasure. (Sprite reward one person, sylph a small party.)

Hate Salt

Passive: 70 Essence & 60 Alchemy

Analyze: 120 Essence

Fay will avoid crossing lines of salt, as it creates a particular essence vapor that wards them off. Consider making a circle of salt for protection.

Wild Magic

Passive: 80 Essence

Analyze: 130 Essence

A Kelpie’s festival is a rare but wonderful blessing. Disturbing the peace will risk being cursed.

Eternal, Unforgiving

Passive: 100 Essence

Analyze: 150 Essence

The Middron can wreathe itself in storms and be summoned by an ally to seek revenge.

Specific Triggers

Passive: 100 Essence or 130 Common

Analyze: 150 Essence

Re-creating or emulating whatever activity first spawned the fay will cause them to become hostile. They will not trust you or forgive you.

Sprite: Abuse of the young, poor, or defenseless.

Sylph: Abandonment or betrayal of close bonds.

Kelpie: Dishonesty or sexual violation.

Middron: Mass killing or racialized murder.

Wisp/Fairy: Any or no reason (some just exist).

Seeking Liberation

Passive: 150 Essence & 170 Nature

Analyze: 220 Essence

Hearing a fay’s story is the least you can do, but often, the root of evil that spawned them must be faced. Dragons have been known to free fay too.

Across Time and Planes

Passive: 200 Essence or 250 Alchemy

Analyze: 270 Essence

The Kelpie can create and access chronocules (for use by those that can enter the Plane of Change). Fairies can not only enter the Plane of Change, but bring others into it. Both only do these things with their closest, most trusted friends.

“Today marks 1000 years of keeping record of the Fay and their tales. May we always listen.”

- Sha Stand, VNFC Period, Issue #501, the Complete Collection

Behavior

All fay have significant depth of emotion (just in different ways). In general, they do not default to violence and (with the exception of Middron) are opposed to violent exchanges.

Fay consider themselves genderless, even if they have engendered mannerisms (some may act masculine or feminine, but this is just a projection of human values onto their behavior). They do not especially care for gender.

Wisps, sprites, and fairies are all quite playful and childlike and enjoy mischief. They do not understand the concept of property, only the concept of needs being met. However, it is clear that they at least understand that many do not share their philosophy, which apparently tickles them. They enjoy stealing to meet their needs, especially against the stingy or selfish.

Sylph are friendly but sorrowful and often sing or play instruments. They are known to haunt traveling groups or parties for days at a time, playing distant melodies. Rarely they will manifest themselves, but more often to solo travelers.

Kelpie are talkative, trusting, bubbly, and known for speaking truth to things. This is especially famous given that kelpie love to tease and roast and joke about traveller’s worst traits, no matter how brutal or embarassing this might be. They believe that bold truth is the only truth you can trust.

Middron are heavy, slow to act, contemplative, but capable of incredible anger. While most tales of Middron are haunting and tense, they do have a variety of character. Often they can be found reading, writing, or thinking deeply on subjects and sometimes they can even be boisterous or friendly (towards old friends). However, the many stories of their violent potential are not without merit.

Habitat and Life

Fay are creatures that simultaneously shift between the Grounded Realm (also called the Mundane, which is the physical, inhabited world) and the Essence Realm. Some believe that the foyer of the Essence Realm (the Plane of Essence) belongs to them because they spend so much time there.

Fay bodies can be physical, but this is inconsequential - they cannot die. Typically when a physical form expires, the essence tied to it will also expire. But fay’s essence is tied to something else, usually a task or quest that they must complete. Because of this, they often reisde in a specific locality their entire lives. Wisps and Fairies are a known exception to this, however. They are sometimes tied to a community or person and may be found travelling with them).

Fay are “born” (if you will) out of the wake of certain activities, like living ramifications. These activities are almost always traumatic. Because of this, the area in which they are born is often of great significance to them. Fay live with a deep sense of purpose (but never impatient) which involves bringing balance to counter the trauma that was inflicted.

Fay do not need to eat or drink and do not reproduce. Despite the inconsequential nature of their bodies, fay do sleep. It is theorized that they don’t sleep because they need it (in a physical sense) but because it brings them joy.

Histories and Cultures

The fayfolk tribes have coexisted with wisps and fairies since before written history and even gain their second life from the power of elder fairies. They highly revere all fay.

While most cultures have a deep respect for fay (and killing them is generally considered horrendous), most don’t understand them and are wary.

Notably the empire states, like Tacklesbard or the Kaldaki, will sometimes regard fay as a nuisance. Often imperial politicians or heads of state will discuss fay in delicate terms, in an attempt to avoid offending their pro-fay citizens. It is theorized that the activity of imperialism is the exact opposite of all that fay stand for and are the cause of most fayspawning across Braven. If true, this would certainly be a good reason why empires and fay don’t get along.

All that being said, fay do not seem to particularly regard (or even recognize) nations or states.

Notes for Playing as

Think narratively first (over combat). Every fay is an embodiment of some event, a living history. Have your players experience and explore the tale, even consider avoiding “solving” anything.

Wisp (Fayling)

Evanesce2

50 Stamina

Shift into the Essence Realm, making your physical body disappear and become untargetable. You may only be targeted by spells and only if the caster can see your essence.

While in the Essence Realm you can fly (move in any direction) and gain Essence Sight but cannot use any other abilities. You may cancel this effect at any time.

Form Bond

5Min, 8SN, target must consent

Both you and a target you trust (in sight) will form a subconscious bond to one another and will share non-verbal communication, comprension, and compassion for one another that can be experienced at any distance. You understand each others’ thoughts and feelings. This is permanent until cancelled by either you or your target or one of you dies. If one of you dies, the survivor takes [4d6+12 SN] Damage. May only have one bond at a time.

Request Aid2

7PT & 1d6SN

Beckon a plant with a power of [2d20+60] at your feet in front of you. Must be standing on soil or plant matter. See Dismiss/Beckon Flora in the Red Book for more details.

~Passives~

Liminal, Wholesomeness

Evaporate into essence upon death. Will revive if another Fay touches your essence or within 1d3 weeks. When you revive, you begin with Evanesce active at the current location of your essence.

Give [+1d6] to target’s SN Regen. May only use once per day per target & only on targets you trust.

Attack (No Attacks, see Request Aid)

Defense (See Abilities), 60 (=PT, Dodge)

Beg2

3PT & 3SN

Ask all targets in sight for food, if they have any on them (you can see their items with Thru-Sight).

Blink2

1 Use of Move, may stack

Can use Move at any time to teleport to target location, up to the distance allowed by Move. This may also be used to grab an unheld item in sight (typically used if a target refuses your Beg).

Evanesce2

50 Stamina

Shift into the Essence Realm, making your physical body disappear and become untargetable. You may only be targeted by spells and only if the caster can see your essence.

While in the Essence Realm you gain Essence Sight but can only use Blink (and only to move). You may cancel this effect at any time.

~Passives~

Liminal, Thru-Sight, Wholesomeness

Evaporate into essence upon death. Will revive if another Fay touches your essence or within 1d3 weeks. When you revive, you begin with Evanesce active at the current location of your essence.

Can see through physical objects.

Give [+1d6+2] to target’s SN Regen. May only use once per day per target & only on targets you trust.

Complete Languor

50 SN

All who have either full or less than 0 Sanity are afflicted with your psychic melody. Targets fall into unwakeable sleep for 3 days. May spend 1 Plot Point per additional target you wish to include.

Echo2

3PT & 10SN, 3 uses per target per day

Target sees, hears, or smells something from one of their memories (of your choosing) within [20u] of their location. They lose (or gain) [4d20 Sanity].

Evanesce2

50 Stamina

Shift into the Essence Realm, making your physical body disappear and become untargetable. You may only be targeted by social spells and only if the caster can see your essence.

While in the Essence Realm you gain Essence Sight and may use Echo and Move. You may cancel this effect at any time.

~Passives~

Deeply Empathetic, Liminal

Can see all targets’ memories and feel what they felt. Know all targets’ current Sanity.

Evaporate into essence upon death. Will revive if another Fay touches your essence or within 1d3 weeks. When you revive, you begin with Evanesce active at the current location of your essence.

Kelpie

Level 20

+10 Plot Points

Languages

Dark-tongue (3), Fay (3), Old Nia (3), The Sea (3), Therion (3), & Choice (3)

Size: Large

Occupies: 1x3x2 (1u wide, 3u long, 2u tall).

Evanesce2

50 Stamina

Shift into the Essence Realm, making your physical body disappear and become untargetable. You may only be targeted by social spells and only if the caster can see your essence.

While in the Essence Realm you gain Essence Sight and may use any abilities. You may cancel this effect at any time.

Save Chronocule

7PT & 69 from Max SN

While using Evanesce, you choose a physical object to store a snapshot of time and space at that moment and location. It becomes a chronocule. The chronocule may be retrieved 4 times and then the 69 Sanity is returned to your maximum.

You will only create this chronocule at someone’s request, only if you trust them deeply, they have never lied to you or violated anyone in a sexual way, and they (or their allies) spend 20 Plot Points.

The chronocule must stay within [80u] of the location it was created or it cannot be retrieved.

Retrieve Chronocule

2Min & 20SN

While using Evanesce, you touch a target and send them through a chronocule’s portal, back to the moment the chronocule was saved (consuming one charge). Target must be with you in the Essence Realm when you cast this (note that fairies can help bring someone into the Essence). See Retrieve/Save Chronocule in the Red Book.

Attack 8d20+d100+100 (Portaled Spell)

Defense (See Evanesce)

S. Resist 115, Lore Type: Essence

Move 8/6 INI 10 PT 18

Stam 800 SN 310,+31 DH 100

Conjure Curse

18PT, 1SN, & 3d6 from Max SN

Target within [40u] is cursed. The SN spent from rolling and the reagents used determine the type of curse that is applied. See Green Book for details.

Revel

3Hours, 100SN, & 2 Plot Points

Create a celebration of wine, mana, and honey suitable for up to 100 attendees (any creature can attend). During the feast, any target that hurts another and is not forgiven by the end of the celebration automatically Curses themselves (they spend the Sanity and lose Max Sanity).

Feast lasts for 7 days. During this time, none go without food or drink and all uses of Sleep are critically effective. At the end of the revelry, all attendees that are not cursed benefit from your Wholesomeness (even if not near you) for as many days as they participated in the celebration.

~Passives~

Hydrophillic, Liminal, Powerful Spirit, Wholesomeness

Can breathe water. Swim costs normal Move.

Evaporate into essence upon death. Will revive if another Fay touches your essence or within 1d3 weeks. When you revive, you begin with Evanesce active at the current location of your essence.

You can Roast targets for 0PT at any time, which removes their chance to crit or have positive, open ended rolls. Roast is also a form of divination that can reveal hidden truths about your target.

Give [+2d6+3] to target’s SN Regen. May only use once per day per target & only on targets you trust.

Middron

Level 28

Languages

Fay (3), The Dead (3), Therion (3), & Choice (3)

Size: Huge

Occupies: 3x1x5 (3u wide, 1u deep, 5u tall).

Bequeath Vengeance2

Target must spend 10 Plot Points

Target you trust may summon you for a fight (or a chance) where you can exact your vengeance.

Evanesce2

50 Stamina

Shift into the Essence Realm, making your physical body disappear and become untargetable. You may only be targeted by social spells and only if the caster can see your essence.

While in the Essence Realm you may use Move for [4PT] less (Move cannot cost less than 1PT). You may cancel this effect at any time.

Storm

12PT, 3d6SN, & (30SN or 3 Plot Points)

Damage: [16 Health + 8d20+800 Stamina]

Info: Natural Lightning (SK), 6 Base PT

Create a raging storm that follows you for 3 rounds with a radius equal to the [3d6] roll for Sanity spent. Vision is occluded in the storm’s radius. All attacks, defenses, and maneuvers that use sight within the radius are reduced by [80].

At the start of each turn the storm is active, every unit with a target occupying it within the radius has a one in three chance (5 or 6 on a d6) to be struck by a bolt of lightning from the storm. Each attack hits the entire unit, placing randomly (using the glance table) as if it were an Immense attack. Damage is increased by [160 Stamina] if target body part hit is wet or in metal armor.

Attack 2d20+d100+80 (Melee Weapon)

Defense (Will not defend against attacks)

Release2

50 Sanity or 5 Plot Points

All beckoned plants and animals, controlled husks, and targets (that you trust) with possession charges in sight are set free of their bindings.

Vanquish

12PT, 50 Stam, & 1d3+3d6 SN

Damage: [6d6+20 Health + 12d20+625 Stamina]

Info: 2H Melee (CH+SL), 6 Base PT

Effect: Knock the target back [1d3u] or hit an adjacent target for half damage.

~Passives~

2nd Wind I, Brawn, Master of Power, Prevention, Size Advantage, Size Disadvantage, Relentless, Unveiling Rage

Once per day when Stamina reaches below 1950, heal [28d20+560 Stamina].

Double Trauma effects.

Hitting legs removes 1 Move Counter from foe.

Huge: Attacks have +1 Melee Range.

Huge: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Small-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost much more PT.

2 Opportunities per turn. Can use Move as an Opportunity to move towards a target that leaves your line of sight. Can use Vanquish as an Opportunity if you end movement within [1u] of a target.

Have Essence Sight and can see in total darkness/occlusion. Know all the names and faces that a target has ever killed or physically harmed. If you consent, you can become a medium for any dead that desire to speak through you.
