Weapon Two 10

Erudition 60

Alchemy Lore 100

Common Lore 100

Essence Lore 100

*Nature Lore 400

*Wits 170

Awareness 220

Craftiness 300

Inscription 220

Tactics 220

Prestige 65

Authority 120

Charisma 120

Nerve 65

Courage 200

Willpower 200

Owi’wi’l’mekq’ (“Wiwil”)

Owi’wi’l’mekq’ (pronounced ah-wee-wee-l-meh-qua), referred to in Colonial as “Wiwils” (pronounced wee-will, or plural as wee-wills) are giant, purple or blue gastropods (snails and slugs). Their enormous bodies are long, slick, and expand and retract as they slowly and quietly move themselves forward, leaving thick slime behind. Both kinds of wiwil have two tentacles that stick off the tops of their heads with eyes on the tips and two tentacles on either side of their face, next to their mouth for grabbing. All four tentacles are retractable. Their mouths are gaping circles that almost entirely account for the face of their body and are filled with thousands of small, diamond-hard teeth. S’lib’l’q’ (pronounced s-lib-l-qua, or as “Slibe”) have shells, while g’lub’l’q’ (pronounced g-lub-l-qua, or as “Gloob”) do not.

Sticky Slime

Passive: 10 Nature* or 20 Alchemy

Analyze: 40 Nature

The slime can be a hazard when traveling, so watch your step and avoid crossing it with a caravan or trailer. It takes 12-24 hours to evaporate.

Not Weak to Salt

Passive: 20 Nature or 30 Alchemy

Analyze: 50 Nature

Unlike garden variety gastropods, wiwils are not negatively affected by salt. They actually like it!

Farmed for Dye

Passive: 30 Nature and 30 Alchemy

Analyze: 60 Nature

The slime of a wiwil can be turned into blue or purple dye by boiling it until it dries into powder.

“The owi’wi’l’mekq’ give many gifts; from them the dragon’s drill, lessons of patience, frugality...”

- Anonymous God, Shik-fal Scrolls

Behavior

Wiwil are slow moving and have very little aggression, even when threatened. They do have incredibly dangerous teeth and can consume entities whole, so they are not to be underestimated.

Despite their capability to eat people, this is still a rare occurance. They are completely uninterested in travelers, adventurers, or people in general.

Habitat and Life

Wiwil live all over Braven and are considered one of the oldest creatures by both cultural and scientific record, second only to wyverns.

Many cave systems and caverns have been created by wiwils, who always “mine” their “food” safely and sustainably. They migrate and fill in when structural integrity is at stake. The most famous cave system by wiwils are the cliffs of Whisper Ridge, which whistle from the holes they bore.

Wiwils are hermaphroditic and can reproduce using both of their sexual organs at once, laying eggs approximately one month later.

However, wiwil more commonly mate with multiple partners at once. The process can take weeks and is very dangerous for anything in the region, due to the collective size of the sexual troupe.

Histories and Cultures

Wiwil are regarded in many cultures as metaphors for patience, sustainability, frugality, and sobriety. Historically, many have farmed wiwil slime for dye, but recently rogues have begun to slay them for a chance at gems. The only records of wiwil attacking humans have been in this latter case.

Notes for Playing as

Think of their narrative value if added to a scene or battle. They can passively add environment hazards to almost anything!

Geophagic

Passive: 40 Nature or 40 Alchemy

Analyze: 70 Nature

Wiwil primarily eat plants, amber, rocks, clay, dirt, minerals, and metals.

Get eaten? Will shit.

Passive: 50 Nature

Analyze: 80 Nature

Wiwil digest relatively fast and don’t metabolize flesh... If you wait, you might live!

Gem-filled Bellies

Passive: 70 Nature & 70 Alchemy

Analyze: 100 Nature

Carefully dissecting a wiwil could produce rare gems (due to the quantity of stones and ore that they regularly eat). Is it worth it though?

G’lub’l’q’ (“Gloob”)

Level 7

Languages

The Sea (3) & Therion (3)

Size: Immense

Occupies: 4x12x3 (4u wide, 12u long, 3u tall)

Attack (No Attack Rolls)

Defense (3PT, Hide Antennae in Face)

S. Resist 89, Lore Type: Nature

Move 2/3 INI -6 PT 10

Stam 550 SN 40 DH 75

Face

MIT 3 | 40%

Evade -50

Health 300

R Top Antenna

MIT 0 | 20%

Evade 0

Health 55

R Face Antenna

MIT 0 | 20%

Evade 0

Health 55

Chest

MIT 3 | 40%

Evade -50

Health 800

L Top Antenna

MIT 0 | 20%

Evade 0

Health 55

L Face Antenna

MIT 0 | 20%

Evade 0

Health 55

Consume

1PT, Requires at least 1 Face Antenna

Damage: [d6+12 Health + 3d20+90 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (ML), 6 Base PT, [4u] wide

Open your mouth for one round, removing face MIT. If moving, you consume Huge (and smaller) sized targets completely that are in your way. Targets move through your digestive system at a rate of [3u] per round. You are [12u] long. Targets take the damage from this attack every round they remain in your belly (attack still places randomly). Targets may use Struggle against your belly strength of [140] if they wish to use Tactical Shift during their turn (to either move up instead of down [3u] or speed digestion downwards).

~Passives~

Amphibious Gastropod, Leisurely, Retractables, Slimy, Size Adv/Disadv.

See 360 degrees and breathe both water and air.

You can only move in one direction each turn.

You can hide any antennae in your face for 3PT.

You leave a [4u] wide trail of slime behind you, which halves Move distance across it. Lasts 12hrs.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

Consume

1PT, Requires at least 1 Face Antenna

Damage: [d6+12 Health + 3d20+90 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (ML), 6 Base PT

Open your mouth for one round, removing face MIT. If moving, you consume Huge (and smaller) sized targets completely that are in your way. Targets move through your digestive system at a rate of [3u] per round. You are [12u] long. Targets take the damage from this attack every round they remain in your belly (attack still places randomly). Quietus

Quietus (pronounced kai-AE-duss) are huge hounds, with lengthy, gaunt white faces of exposed bone and thin, stretched smiles of sharp, crooked fangs. Behind their bony snout is a skinless face and shining, black little eyes on either side of their skull. Their mane is a crown of black spines that grow down the quietus’ back and chest. Their stiff, hearty tail is also covered in spines, from base to tip. The rest of their body is covered in soft fur that can range in length according to the climate and also range in color from black, brown, tan, to off-white and sometimes a mix.

Beware Raised Spines

Passive: 50 Nature*

Analyze: 80 Nature

If a quietus raises its spines, it senses danger and may preemptively attack.

Spines Strike Back

Passive: 60 Nature

Analyze: 90 Nature

If attacked, quietus may reactively shoot spines.

Avoid the Rain Runs

Passive: 70 Nature

Analyze: 120 Nature

For a 10-day period each year leading to the first eclipse of the rainy season, quietus go mad and “rain run” in massive, rampaging stampedes. Avoid the seashore and western shores of rivers.

“Your Dog Came Back? Research observes unique essence signatures across quietus generations.”

- Sha Stand , VNFC Period, Issue #525, the Complete Collection

Behavior

Quietus are fierce when they need to be and fairly cautious otherwise. Despite this, they can have a breadth of personalities and behaviors ranging in spectrum from grumpy and aloof to teasing and playful. There are no two quietus alike.

Quietus do experience mood swings at times, between depression and cheerfulness. Because of this, quietus can be understanding and forgiving in relationships when shown patience in return.

Habitat and Life

Quietus do not have natural gifts for regulating temperature, and therefore avoid fierce heat and cold. They favor the temperate and rainy northern regions of Braven, anywhere between Irris Wood and Minerocca.

They have been spotted as south as the Hawdorians or Ancient’s Sod, but these are rare exceptions.

In the wild quietus rear their young in small packs, typically with just one other adult (their mate). Quietus take up to two decades to grow out of their pup phase. After 10 years, the pup pack leaves their parents and sets out as their own pack for another 10. Then as adult hounds, quietus can wander alone or with just a mate for decades more before having a litter of their own.

Histories and Cultures

While they can appear ugly, quietus are mostly wonderful beasts and close friends to humankind in many northern cultures. They are loyal and enjoy developing lifelong bonds.

Oddly, they have grown rarer in recent years.

Notes for Playing as

Don’t just treat quietus like a mount or a foe, they can be as complex, wonderful, and tragic as any NPC would in a story.

Incredible Trackers

Passive: 90 Nature or 100 Essence

Analyze: 140 Nature

Quietus can track the scent of essence, making them unparalleled hunters.

Self-Sacrificing

Passive: 120 Nature and 120 Essence

Analyze: 190 Nature

Quietus can give their lives to undo the effects of a short period of time, even reversing death.

Eternal Cycle

Passive: 130 Nature and 130 Essence

Analyze: 200 Nature

There are only a few unique quietus souls and they cycle with each new litter of pups. During the Rain Runs, quietus remember their old lives.

Quietus Pup

Quietus

Level 32

+6 Plot Points

Adult quietus during the rain runs.

Naturalist Skollyson, “Archives from before the 1st Era.”

Languages

Therion (3)

Size: Huge

Occupies: 2x4x3 (2u wide, 4u long, 3u tall).

Sacrifice

100% Stamina, Sanity, & Death Health

Give up your life and die for a friend. Nothing can prevent or undo your death, even time magic, demonic deals, or another’s Sacrifice. You may choose one of two outcomes for this move, if you have met the requirements:

Timeskip: You reverse your friend back in time to the state they were in up to 1 full round earlier. This will remove any curses, diseases, poisons, damage, and even death received during this last round. They do not teleport or move in any way, only their body’s state is returned to them.

Timescotch: Your friend’s current state will return to them in two turns. Any effects they receive until then will be undone, similar to Timeskip. However, Timescotch also returns the state of your friend’s held items and gear.

Requirement: You and your friend both must have purchased Did We Just Become Best Friends? as a Shape Choice with one another in order to enable the use of this move.

Spinal Shot

Free once per turn (may also trigger)

Damage: [d6+18 Health + 4d20+290 Stamina]

Info: Missile Attack (PU), 15u Range, 6 Base PT

You start with one counter and gain an additional counter each time you are hit by an attack that deals damage. On your turn, you may shoot as many spines as you have counters.

Bork2

~Passives~

Double Trauma effects.

Huge: Attacks have +1 Melee Range.

Huge: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Small-sized and smaller entities. Some moves cost much more PT.

Add [+4d6 Health] damage per Trauma Level.

Courage 70

Willpower 50

Remnants

Remnants are utterly titanic humanoid-looking constructs comprised of stone, seams of clay, patches of metal, and magic gems in place of eyes which shine sharp beams of light. Remnants all have stone crowns on their heads with stone seats inside. Aside from these common traits, there are 3 distinct subtypes: golems are sometimes just a messy assembly of boulders and stones in the shape of a giant humanoid. Other times they are well made with human-like features and proportions. Functionally there is little difference. The gargoyle are named so because they resemble gargoyles from mirthic architecture. They are the smallest remnant and always have wings. Their stonework and details are excellent: clawed hands, defined muscles, horns, and sometimes massive, metal swords. Titans are the largest of the three types by an order of magnitude. Titans are always crafted to look like specific characters, likely their original creators or as a tribute to someone, including clothes and other gear.

Unyielding

Passive: 50 Alchemy

Analyze: 80 Alchemy

Remnants are immune to poison, disease, social maneuvers, have no sanity, take no bleeding or stun effects, and have no lungs or eyes.

Some Weaknesses

Passive: 70 Alchemy*

Analyze: 100 Alchemy

Remnants can’t heal limb health and have almost no spell resist. Critical strikes hit their clay seams, bypassing all MIT and fire immunity.

Hated by Dragons

Passive: 80 Alchemy or 60 Nature

Analyze: 110 Alchemy

Remnants are immune to fire and can detect the presence of dragonstone from great distances, making them the perfect predators of dragons.

Tend to Stay Put

Passive: 90 Alchemy

Analyze: 120 Alchemy

Remnants will sometimes (but not always) avoid leaving an area. Are they bound to it?

Reveal The Conduit

Passive: 100 Alchemy

Analyze: 150 Alchemy

Remnants all have a small, fleshy nodule called a “conduit” under a layer of rock on the top of their head, inside their stony crown. The conduit sits in a hollow chamber like a brain in a nearly empty head, stuck to the base of its enclosure. The remnant’s head must be damaged enough to break open the rock layer above it to get to the “brain” inside. The conduit is a remnant’s greatest weakspot: it has no immunities or armor and it can bleed and apply stun to the remnant.

Possessed by Godless

Passive: 110 Alchemy or 90 Nature

Analyze: 160 Alchemy

It appears as though most all remnants still functioning are actually controlled by environmental essence (called “Godless”). Dealing with remnants in the same way one would with Deathless might make things easier (assuming the remnant is not being harnessed by a powerful sorcerer). This new insight explains why some (but not all) golemic constructs in recent history tend not to wander far.

Constructed Legally

Passive: 140 Alchemy or 140 Essence

Analyze: 190 Alchemy

The bodies of remnants are actually constructed legally. It just requires an absolutely massive amount of time, sanity, materials and a licensable rune for forging the materials. The real question is, how does one make the stones come alive?

Birthed Using Flesh

Passive: 170 Alchemy & 170 Common

Analyze: 240 Alchemy

The “incubation” of the golemic birth-cycle begins by violently mashing many living people together in a “constructor’s pen.” The flesh is then drained of essence, separating bodies from souls. Both flesh and essence are congealed separately and then recombined. This process kills all the participants and destroys their souls. The resulting flesh node is the Conduit. Now the trick is how to connect it to the stone and control it...

Mirthic Shards, the Key

Passive: 200 Alchemy & 200 Essence

Analyze: 270 Alchemy

Shards of Mirthic Essence link conduits to objects. These shards are one-time use, and may no longer exist. Mirthics had physical essence (unlike others) but all died long ago in the Great Trauma.

“Mirthics created titans, yet destroyed themselves with something even worse? Harrowing.”

- Aaryahi Chakrabarti, Ancient Crimes and Early Golemics

Behavior

Remnant behavior can be difficult to classify because they are animated by another’s whim.

If they are animated via a Godless, then their behavior is generally motivated by a desire to fend off intruders or seek vengeance due to something that has been done to the environment (like resource extraction, habitation, or invasion).

If remnants are animated by a powerful wizard? They are likely to behave like a powerful sorcerer would if they had a gigantic, city-destroying body. Maybe used to kill dragons or wipe out a hamlet or win a battle or impress a love interest, who knows? Wizards can be terrible.

Aside from speculatory motivations, remnants are limited in their behavior mechanically. They are slow, with predictable movements and little dexterity. Due to their size, they will almost never be employed in a stealthy approach. They also have no eyes, ears, mouths, (or whatever else) so they make for poor conversation partners.

Habitat and Life

Theoretically remnants can be found anywhere on land or sea. Since dragons used to dwell in the mountains, many remnant shells can be found there. In addition, since dragons used to live far into The Deep, away from the Braven Sea, many remnants still remain there as well.

Most remnants that existed around the populated areas of Braven have been broken down, decomissioned, and turned into statues or monuments that remind the world of what horrors people are capable of.

During the Great Trauma, remnants weren’t completely without casualties or damage. This means that there are plenty of remnants missing limbs, digits, or are in various states of disarray. It is actually rare to encounter a remnant or remnant shell in pristine condition.

Histories and Cultures

The first records of humanity all begin with a description of the same event (but from different perspectives): the Great Trauma, or the Culling of the Dragons.

Long ago, the Mirthics of the First Moon created golems, gargoyles, and titans to hunt down and kill every living dragon in Braven. A mysterious weapon used in the mirthics’ civil war destroyed their moon and killed them all. This deactivated all remnants, ending the dragon’s persecution.

After this event, the remaining people of Braven (once slaves of the mirthics working in segregated colonies) were free to organize societies as they saw fit.

The only universally agreed upon measure was that the remnants would be dismantled, destroyed, and the technologies used to create them would be be eliminated.

Avoiding the reproduction of this monstrous technology also brought with it a long period of little to no insight into how such a thing was possible or how to deactivate the ones that seem to appear every now and then.

This ancient decision has become a hotly controversial target. Atypical alliances have formed between rogue academics and military leaders, pacifistic anarchists and monarchs, and involving the public in what would normally have been a pretty esoteric debate.

Over the last few thousand years, most meaningful, practical, and peaceful things about remnants have been researched. So the real controversy is whether certain political figures are interested in employing remnants again and what impact an arms race would have on global stability.

Notes for Playing as

Remnants are interesting as a tool of a Godless: they don’t really have to be fought but just deactivated. But a remnant used by an evil cabal of wizards? Reserve that kind of campaign for only your highest level party.

Remnants should first be employed as narrative enemies (destroying a city or killing a dragon) as your party can then choose to run, hide, or focus on other efforts (such as evacuating the town, etc). Most of all: set up their first encounter as something they can learn from. Remnants can be punishing, so let them live to fight another day.

Golem

Level 35

Languages

Occupies: 6x3x10 (6u wide, 3u deep, 10u tall).

9PT

15PT

Damage: [6d20+1600 Stamina]

Info: H2H Attack (SM), 6 Base PT

Effects: Grab all Large or smaller entities on target unit and completely constrict them in your hand with a strength of [450], dealing damage. If you already have targets in your hand, throw them [2d20+20u] and deal damage.

Note: Targets that roll at least [100 Awareness or Tactics] and defending with an out-of-turn movement ability have the option to move onto your arm as you grab, instead of out of the way.

~Passives~

Brawn/Violent, Clay Seams, In Ruins, No Autonomy, Of Stone, Size Adv/Disadv, Vulnerable Conduit

Triple Trauma Effects.

Critical strikes against you ignore your MIT and ignore your immunity to Fire.

Do once: You are likely damaged, partially sunken, or eroding. Roll [4d20+20] for the percent health each limb (except your conduit) starts with.

You can not use any Erudition, Wits, Prestige, or Nerve maneuvers. If applicable, your controller may use these maneuvers instead.

Immune to Poison, Disease, Social Maneuvers, Sanity Loss, Stun, Bleeding, and Fire and Death Health Damage. You have no lungs, eyes, or ears and take no negative effects related to them. You can detect dragonstone within [10000u]. You don’t sleep and cannot regen Stamina or any Health.

Immense: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +2 Melee Range and will hit an entire unit. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Immense: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Medium-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost considerably more PT.

Your conduit is the only way you can receive Fire and Death Health Damage or Bleeding and Stun effects. However, your conduit is only targetable if your Head Health has been reduced to [0] or attacks have been made specifically against the top of your head and reduced its health by [50%].

Titan

Level 100

Languages

Brace2

Heave

33PT, may use once every other turn

Damage: [24d20+5500 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (SM + BL), 6 Base PT

Effects: Lean down and shovel your hands under terrain or an Immense entity or object. At the beginning of your next turn you will flip whatever is in your hands. If terrain, you can flip a [15x12] area back on another [15x12] or throw a [6x6] at another [6x6] within [60u]. All targets flipped or hit by fliped terrain take this move’s damage.

Note: Targets may move onto your arms before you flip. However, they must use [Balance or Arm Muscle + 50] against your [d100 + 110] to hold on or else fall off and take Heave’s damage.

Pulverize

22PT, free to use once per turn

Damage: [50 Health + 20d20+5000 Stamina]

Info: Weapon Attack (SM + SL), 6 Base PT

Siphon2

Controller-only, once use per turn

Your connection to your controller allows them to transfer up to [10000 Stamina] from themselves to you. Note: Environmental essence will only do this once, but other controllers may differ.

Attack (No Attack Rolls)

Defense (See Brace)

Move 15/11 INI -2 PT 44

~Passives~

Brawn/Violent, Clay Seams, In Ruins, Level, No Autonomy, Of Stone, Size Adv/Disadv, Vulnerable Conduit

Triple Trauma Effects.

Critical strikes against you ignore your MIT and ignore your immunity to Fire.

Do once: You are likely damaged, partially sunken, or eroding. Roll [10d6+40] for the percent health each limb (except your conduit) starts with.

Cannot fumble. Low rolls are just low rolls!

You can not use any Erudition, Wits, Prestige, or Nerve maneuvers. If applicable, your controller may use these maneuvers instead.

Immune to Poison, Disease, Social Maneuvers, Sanity Loss, Stun, Bleeding, and Fire and Death Health Damage. You have no lungs, eyes, or ears and take no negative effects related to them. You can detect dragonstone within [10000u]. You don’t sleep and cannot regen Stamina or any Health.

Colossal: No attack roll is made. Instead, attacks have +3 Melee Range and hit 3 units in a line in any direction. Attacks place randomly using glance table on each target occupying the unit unless targets use Block or are able to move from the unit.

Colossal: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Large-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost significantly more PT.

Your conduit is the only way you can receive Fire and Death Health Damage and Bleeding and Stun effects. However, your conduit is only targetable if your Head Health has been reduced to [0] or attacks have been made specifically against the top of your head and reduced its health by [50%].

*Physique 550

Arm Muscle 725

Leg Muscle 725

Wellness 100

Med/Rest 100

Toughness 275

Grace 5

Balance/Steer 150

Dexterity -20

Courage N/A

Willpower N/A

Scudgies

Scudgies are small, gelatin-like, single-cell fungi (technically yeasts) that resemble ovoid balloons or sagging bubbles. They vary in girth, from one to three times the size of an adult hume’s head. They transport themselves by rolling in a slow, bobbing manner or leaping. If they sit still long enough, they will droop flat. They are translucent green, silver, teal, or black and their cell surface shines like glass when clean because it is textureless and smooth. In light, their cellular contents are visible.

Painful, but Avoidable

Passive: 10 Alchemy*

Analyze: 40 Alchemy

Scudgies can cause burns or paralysis if touched but are slow and incapable of climbing.

Accidental Predators

Passive: 20 Alchemy

Analyze: 50 Alchemy

Scudgies can decompose anything and especially favor organic matter. They are dangerous.

Easy to Track

Passive: 30 Alchemy or 30 Nature

Analyze: 60 Alchemy

Scudgie trails are easy to spot, since they decompose all plants they touch. They leave bobbing, black carbon marks on the ground.

“The first test of the novice alchemist is to dissect a scudgie without touching the membrane.”

- Ri Richus, Alchemy

Behavior

Scudgie have impressive capacity for coordination considering they don’t possess a “brain.” In large numbers, they appear to work together towards the same general aim: killing, consuming, and decomposing organic proteins and sugars.

Scudgie are capable of leaping, especially when excited by the possibility of fleshy food to eat, which makes them difficult to engage in large numbers.

Habitat and Life

Scudgie are incredibly resilient to virtually every climate, even the harshest ones (like the bottom of the ocean or close to volcanoes or in vacuums). They can survive for up to ten years without eating or drinking.

They are capable of reproducing through meiosis with another scudgie (producing 2 children and halving their size each) or through mitosis by themselves (producing one child and halving their size). They only reproduce when they have stored enough energy to do so, which is generally after a couple years of occasional eating.

Scudgie have been recorded with fertile lifespans up to 100 years before they become incapable of reproduction. At this point, they die. 20% of scudgie never reproduce, but instead keep growing.

Histories and Cultures

Scudgie are common, but pretty avoidable. Most cultures treat them as pests, treatable by specialists or novice adventurers. However, they are regarded highly for their research benefits by some.

Notes for Playing as

A devious idea could be to make a “scudgie pit” in a wizard’s lair - a trap that multiplies scudgies with spells until a puzzle is solved.

Good Ingredients

Passive: 40 Alchemy

Analyze: 70 Alchemy

Scudgie nuclei, ribosomes, mitochondria are useful alchemical ingredients. Preserve in sugar!

Don’t Portal Magic!

Passive: 50 Alchemy or 50 Essence

Analyze: 100 Alchemy

Portaling spells on a scudgie can cause it to grow and even immediately force cellular mitosis.

Cause Deathrot

Passive: 130 Alchemy & 130 Nature

Analyze: 200 Alchemy

Subjects that die after recently inhaling a super scudgie’s spores simultaneously with groll pheromones may become a zombie.

Scudgie

Bounce

6PT

Damage: [0 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (SM), 6 Base PT

Bounce at a target up to [2u] away and two units high, in an attempt to inflict pain from your membrane. If you miss your target or are dodged, you move one unit behind them along your path of travel. If you hit the target, or are blocked or parried, you return to your starting position. If target blocks or parries and rolls [d100 + Balance or Orientation] greater than [85], they may launch you up to [5u] in the direction of their choice.

~Passives~

-osis time/Chance to Evolve, Pain in the Membrane, Spellsugars

-osis time: If your Body Health max becomes greater than [30], immediately split into two scudgies, each with half your current max Body Health. You may also Bounce into another scudgie if you both have more than [20] health and each produce 2 scudgies in the same way.

Chance to Evolve: 20% of all scudgies are not fertile, so cannot reproduce with mitosis or meiosis. If your health exceeds [30] or another scudgie mates with you, roll [d100] for a 20% chance to become a Super Scudgie and absorb the other scudgie entirely (if applicable).

Any non-scudgie that touches or is touched by your membrane takes a SK attack on location for [d6+12 Health + 2d20 Stamina + 1d3 Stun]. You also gain [+1 Body Health] permanently.

Metabolize portals on you, ignoring spell effects and permanently raising your Body Health max by 5x the base PT, rounds channeled, or minutes of the rune cast (EG 3PT, 3 minutes, or 3 rounds channeled all would increase your max by [+15]).

Attack d100+35 (Bodily Attack)

Defense 85 (3PT, Special Dodge: Flatten Self)

S. Resist -100, Lore Type: Alchemy

Move 2/3, +1 INI 6 PT 6

Stam 200 SN 10 DH 10

Super Scudgie

Bounce

6PT

Damage: [100 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (SM), 6 Base PT

Bounce at a target up to [2u] away and two units high, in an attempt to inflict pain from your membrane. If you miss your target or are dodged, you move one unit behind them along your path of travel. If you hit the target, or are blocked or parried, you return to your starting position. If target blocks or parries and rolls [d100 + Balance or Orientation] greater than [85], they may launch you up to [2u] in the direction of their choice.

Respire

Free, usable once every 3 turns

Bubble up and grow large, losing [20 Evasion] from your Body. At the start of your next turn, spray your fermenting spores in fumes all around you, dealing [2d6+3 Stun] to all non-scudgels in a [9u] radius from you. You return to normal size and heal [50 Stamina] per target hit. This move completes even if you are killed.

~Passives~

Evolutionary Opportunism, Pain in the Membrane, Spellsugars

If you are created due to evolution, you may immediately take a turn before entering the initiative order. After this bonus turn, you will roll and enter the INI order like normal.

Any non-scudgie that touches or is touched by your membrane takes a SK attack on location for [2d6+12 Health + 10d20 Stamina + 1d3 Stun]. You also heal and gain [+5 Body Health].

Metabolize portals on you, ignoring spell effects and healing your Death Health by 10x the base PT, rounds channeled, or minutes of the rune cast (EG 3PT, 3 minutes, or 3 rounds channeled all would heal you [30 Death Health]).

Spectres

Spectres are haunting, dark grey figures that always face toward you, no matter what angle you look at them from. The surface of their body is shrouded in ethereal wafts of dark smoke, rising slowly around them with two piercing black eyes like voids on their bald heads. Their pitch black mouth occasionally emotes and gapes, but makes no sounds. They have a stretched, delicate torso that connects at their base to shadowy areas or nearby surfaces and two long, thin arms weilding a colossal, crooked weapon. Their blade is seamless with their silhouette, also shrouded in smoke. Sometimes they wear hats.

Avoid Being Seen

Passive: 80 Essence*

Analyze: 110 Essence

If any non-essence part of you is visible to them (even in darkness), they can use a teleport attack.

Beware its Pull

Passive: 90 Essence

Analyze: 120 Essence

When they become a seething void, using magic on them has a significant cost to sanity. But if shifting, they are resistant to physical attacks.

Check Your Tethers

Passive: 100 Essence

Analyze: 150 Essence

If you view your own essence threads you can see their face, watching you as they hunt you down.

“assassins working for both demons and humans? A curious yet unsubstantiated hypothesis.”

- E.R. Dyan, The Cosmic Drama: Demons, Dragons, Dieties

Behavior

Spectres are beings conjured to our realm to complete some kind of task. Given that they are very good killers, this tends to be their motivation.

They are completely silent but do communicate and emote using body language and facial expressions. They have personalities and character just like anyone would, minus the talking.

They cycle between three main “modes”: hunting, seething, and shifting. When hunting, spectres can project the visage of their face across threads of essence, to track their prey. When seething, they are vulnerable but also unleash their most dangerous combos. When shifting, they cannot be hurt by physical attacks but have limited abilities and lose their advantage against magic.

Habitat and Life

Little is known about spectres: what do they eat? Do they reproduce? Where do they live? One thing is for sure though: they do need to rest and recover like everyone else.

Histories and Cultures

Some obscure records note rituals for conjuring dark bounty hunters, but these records mistakenly confuse the entities with demons (or at best simply question whether they are real or just fables).

But there can be no doubt that many shady figures through the ages have called on spectres to do their dirty work. They are professional, efficient, and don’t ask questions. Perfect killers.

Notes for Playing as

Spectres don’t have to be conjured to kill your players, but they definitely should be conjured to kill someone. Think of them as bounty hunters. Maybe honorable? Or somehow bought off...

Watch your Step

Passive: 110 Essence

Analyze: 160 Essence

They can place traps on the ground that can teleport you. View these with Essence Sight.

Check Their Tethers

Passive: 120 Essence

Analyze: 170 Essence

Their essence is bound, even after death, to anyone they make a deal with. Trace it back.

Inverse Effect

Passive: 150 Essence & 150 Alchemy

Analyze: 220 Essence

These are Spectres from the Plane of Shadow. Conjuring essence and light together or using weapons of light pyron can cause significant harm.

Shade

Gash

12PT & 3SN

Damage: [28 Health + 3d20+150 Stamina]

Info: Weapon Attack (SL), 9 Base PT

Seethe

12PT & 5SN

Become a seething void of rage until the end of your next turn, replacing your Shifting passive with Manic Sight. You cannot use Move.

Manic Sight: Nothing can hide from you unless out of your line of sight. Your blade teleports and deals [1] Gash attack on up to [4] different targets that are visible to you (at any distance) at the start of your next turn. Spells cast on you pay their Sanity costs again each round for [3] rounds unless they combine Brighten and Conjure Essence.

~Passives~

Abyssal, Light as Smoke, Long Reach, One Form, Shifting

When in darkness, you gain [+25] to Stealth with each darkness level from Normal brightness. In Pitch Black you cannot be seen at all.

Your total WE is [11]. You cannot be knocked back or down. You retain bound essence when you die.

Attacks have +1 Melee Range.

You may distribute remaining Health among your limbs at any time, even as damage is being taken. Your weapon cannot be removed or broken.

Physical attacks deal half damage to you but pass through you and keep going as if they missed. Light Pyron weapons ignore this benefit.

Shadow

Level 45

Languages

Dark-Tongue (3) & Old Nia (3)

Size: Medium

Occupies: 1x1x3 (1u wide, 1u deep, 3u tall).

Delude

1000 Stamina, One use per turn

Your next attack adds [110] to its attack value but your opponent may add their [Awareness Total] to their defense. If the attack hits, it is considered a Sneak Attack and deals double Trauma Points and Effects (doubles Severe passive too). You may use this with Seethe, but it only applies to one attack.

Gash

15PT & 10SN

Damage: [90 Health + 6d20+300 Stamina]

Info: Weapon Attack (SL), 9 Base PT

Special: May use Gash as an Opportunity.

Hunt

18PT & 10SN

Become focused for 1 turn. Gain Essence Sight. You can “feel” essence tethers on objects adjacent to you and project your sight through them. You will be able to see from the location of the tether’s source. However, you cannot see the tethers themselves. Anyone viewing their own essence tethers will be able to see you watching them. You cannot use Seethe while Hunt is active.

Shadowtrap

3PT & 20 Death Health

Pick a unit within sight to create a shadowtrap. The shadowtrap is invisible but can be seen using Essence Sight and lasts for 30 days. Any target that passes over the trap becomes marked. You may activate the shadowtrap for free during your turn, destroying it and teleporting the last entity marked to its location. You can also use Hunt to track your own tether to the shadowtrap and see from its location. May have one at a time.

Attack d100+130 (Melee Weapon)

Seethe

18PT & 5SN

Become a seething void of rage until the end of your next turn, replacing your Shifting passive with Manic Sight. You cannot use Move.

Manic Sight: Nothing can hide from you unless out of your line of sight. Your blade teleports and deals [1] Gash attack on up to [5] different targets that are visible to you (at any distance) at the start of your next turn. You may choose one target to attack twice. All spells cast on you pay their Sanity costs again each round for [4] rounds unless they combine Brighten and Conjure Essence.

~Passives~

Abyssal, Foul, Light as Smoke, Long Reach, One Form, Severe, Shifting

When in darkness, you gain [+25] to Stealth with each darkness level from Normal brightness. In Pitch Black you cannot be seen at all. Light Pyron and spells that combine Brighten and Conjure Essence ignore your Shifting and Manic Sight.

Take Opportunity if an attack crits you.

Your total WE is [13]. You cannot be knocked back or down. You retain bound essence when you die.

Attacks have +1 Melee Range.

You may distribute remaining Health among your limbs at any time, even as damage is being taken. Your weapon cannot be removed or broken.

Add [+10 Health] damage per Trauma Level.

Physical attacks deal half damage to you but pass through you and keep going as if they missed. Light Pyron weapons ignore this benefit.

Level 85

Delude

1000 Stamina, Two uses per turn

Your next attack adds [145] to its attack value but your opponent may add their [Awareness Total] to their defense. If the attack hits, it is considered a Sneak Attack and deals double Trauma Points and Effects (doubles Severe passive too). You may use this with Seethe, but it only applies to one attack.

Return2

5 Plot Points

Teleport to the last location where you used Hunt.

Seethe

24PT & 5SN

Become a seething void of rage until the end of your next turn, replacing your Shifting passive with Manic Sight. You cannot use Move.

Manic Sight: Nothing can hide from you unless out of your line of sight. Your blade teleports and deals [5] Gash attacks, divided among any targets that are visible to you (at any distance) at the start of your next turn. You may teleport behind the last target hit. All spells cast on you pay their Sanity costs again each round for [5] rounds unless they combine Brighten and Conjure Essence.

Shadowtrap

3PT & 20 Death Health

Pick a unit within sight to create a shadowtrap. The shadowtrap is invisible but can be seen using Essence Sight and lasts for 30 days. Any target that passes over the trap becomes marked. You may activate the shadowtrap for free during your turn, destroying it and teleporting the last entity marked to its location. You can also use Hunt to track your own tether to the shadowtrap and see from its location. May have 3 at a time.

Physical attacks deal half damage to you but pass through you and keep going as if they missed. Light Pyron weapons ignore this benefit.

Snipulids

Snipulids are bulbous, glowing, arachnid terrors with eight long, thin, brown limbs which each terminate in a hook-covered pad. They often appear curled up and hanging tightly to a thick entwood branch, mimicing ripe entwood fruit. Their cephalothorax (head region) is quite small, flat, and greenish brown, resembling the fuzzy top of an enwood fruit. Their eight, white eyes are occluded by the fuzz of their head. Their abdomen softly glows with a transluscent, neon-green aquamarine hue. Their abdomen is the size of a half-barrel keg and tear drop shaped with the smaller end connecting to their cephalothorax. When they detect nothing nearby, they occassionaly giggle like an Oku to attract prey.

Glowing Affection

Passive: 30 Nature* or 50 Alchemy

Analyze: 60 Nature

Snipulid venom is debilitating and causes you to glow but these effects are not fatal.

Good Hugs

Passive: 40 Nature

Analyze: 70 Nature

Snipulids have spinnerets on their feet and will hug victims rapidly to wrap and cocoon them.

Sensitive Touch

Passive: 50 Nature

Analyze: 80 Nature

Snipulids’ web strands glow if touched or broken, so you will want to avoid them. Your studies have given you +3d20 to perceiving their locations.

“Snipulid live in hunger with their main prey extinct. Our greed for the fruit keeps them alive.”

- Eoghan Scrivener, On Creatures

Behavior

Snipulid are fairly impatient and opportunistic predators, despite how much time they spend meticulously laying their ground-threads. They don’t even have patience for more than 30% thread coverage in their own hunting area.

Snipulid lives are spent with a constant, sour hunger in their bellies. They are incapable of feeling full. They will scold their “inconsiderate” prey for taking so long to get caught and eaten.

They are shockingly self-centered, prideful, and can quickly grow angry if they realize they are being outsmarted. They hunt in “teems” and giggle at their peers if they catch prey first.

Habitat and Life

Snipulids live primarily in the forested areas around Braven, anywhere entwood can be found (which is just about everywhere). They eat an exclusively carnivorous diet of anything as long as it is as large as a cat but no larger than a horse.

About one in twenty snipulid make it to adulthood. They produce many teemlings, but they eat their young if they get too hungry (or bored).

Histories and Cultures

Snipulids’ gluttony has little regard for sustainable consumption. Long ago they wiped out whatever creature they used to prey on in the woods, slowing down entwood fruit production and inflating its value. The creature they wiped out helped entwood fruit ripen faster.

Notes for Playing as

Sketch thread locations before combat begins to stay honest! Draw straight lines, try to be clever, keep at least 70-75% of units thread-free, and provide a path out. Give players an Oku encounter a few weeks earlier to make a juicy betrayal.

Sweet Looks

Passive: 60 Nature

Analyze: 110 Nature

Snipulids imitate ripe entwood fruit (a sought after treasure). You can now spot the difference.

Delicate Eyes

Passive: 80 Nature

Analyze: 130 Nature

Adult snipulids are nearly blind, only able to see luminescent things like their threads, venom, or other snipulids. You can decoy the threads.

Charming Laughter

Passive: 100 Nature

Analyze: 150 Nature

Snipulids imitate Oku by faintly giggling every few minutes. You can now spot the difference.

Snipulid Teemling

Level 1

Languages

Therion (3)

Size: Small

Occupies: 1x1x1 (1u wide, 1u deep, 1u tall)

Attack d100+30 (Bodily Attack)

Bite

6PT & 25 Stamina

Damage: [2d6 Health + 4d20+265 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (PU), 7 Base PT

Effects: If this attack deals Health Damage and your target’s [Toughness + 50] is less than your roll of [d100 + 35], your venom metabolises. Your venom calms them down and they take [1 Stun]. Their veins pump Luminence, creating a [5u] radius of Normal Brightness around them for 2 turns. If they already have Luminence, refresh the duration and reduce the effectiveness of their next Struggle maneuver by [10]. This can stack.

~Passives~

Dim Vision, False Fruit, of-the-Loom

You can see in up to Dim levels of darkness with no negatives.

When sitting still on an entwood tree, you appear exactly as glowing, unripened entwood fruit.

Your footpads contain thread spinnerets. You are too young to use them yet, but they keep you from illuminating any threads you step on. Your spinnerets allow you to use Move and even hold your position on any surface.

Ripe Snipulid

Level 14

+1 Plot Point

Languages

B’raeim (1), Therion (3), & Choice (2)

Size: Medium

Occupies: 2x2x1 (2u wide, 2u deep, 1u tall).

Wrap

9PT or 1 Plot Point, Requires 4 Legs

Target a unit adjacent to you. Quickly wrap your arms around the closest entity to you on that unit, wrapping them in a thin layer of thread. This attack hits as if it were an Immense attack and does not need to roll. Affected target (if any)must use an out-of-turn Move (to avoid) or Block (to force your attack to hit their shield arm).

You wrap in a horizontal hugging motion, which can wrap multiple body parts at once but places randomly using the glance table. On a humanoid, your glance roll result looks like the following:

Below: Wrap both legs. Target cannot use legs or Move while wrapped and must have [Balance + 50] greater than [d100+75] or get knocked down.

Left or Right: Wrap one arm to chest. Cannot use arm while wrapped.

Target: Wrap both arms to chest. Cannot use either arm while wrapped.

Above: Wrap head. Target becomes Blind and cannot speak.

Wrapped target may use Struggle with [(150% of Arm or Leg Muscle) + 50] against your web strength of [d100+75] to break the web. Your webbing also has [10 Health] and may be broken using an attack. You may wrap the same target multiple times. If you hit the same spot, add [+10 Health] and [+25 Web Strength] to that spot.

When sitting still on an entwood tree, you appear exactly as glowing, ripe entwood fruit.

Your footpads contain thread spinnerets. They keep you from illuminating any threads you step on. Your spinnerets allow you to use Move and even hold your position on any surface. You may optionally lay threads with your spinnerets while moving. Your thread can be detected with [d100+Awareness] against your value of [125].

You can see up to [2u] near you and any entities or thread with Luminance up to [40u], including teemlings and other snipulids.

Willpower 10

Vampires

Vampires are a tricky sort. Their overall appearance is absolutely identical to a human and they often disguise themselves as regular members of society. They wear clothing, armor, and weapons. They don’t actually use their weapons though, because beneath their fingernails are long, razor-thin blades of bone that they can extend and use to devastating effect. They also have long fangs in their mouth, which they can expand when needed. At night, they look the same but their behavior becomes erratic and they lose all their charm and influence.

Feed on Blood

Passive: 10 Alchemy

Analyze: 40 Alchemy

Vampires must consume blood or else go mad.

Weak to Garlic & Light

Passive: 20 Alchemy

Analyze: 50 Alchemy

Vampires are weak to garlic and sunlight.

Creatures of Habit

Passive: 60 Alchemy

Analyze: 110 Alchemy

Vampires don’t actually have weaknesses to sunlight or garlic. They have “cycles” that make them stronger at different things during the day or night. During Dusk they are strongest, but during the Dawn they are the weakest.

“Vampires aren’t a laughable old myth, they are just as dangerous as they were in the first age.”

- Aaryahi Chakrabarti, Ancient Crimes and Early Golemics

Behavior

Vampires behave and act with as broad of a spectrum as regular human folks do, with the one exception that they, well, feed on people. They obsess over this, of course. It is everything to them.

Since vampires were once living, they tend to emulate the behaviors and habits they had from their old life. They try to keep appearances, but more often than not they leave their communities in search of others.

Habitat and Life

Vampires that stay near their homes are the first that get caught, so the real survivors move on and start a new life. They find opportunity in both rural and urban living, each with upsides and downsides to consider.

Not surprisingly, many vampires end up in positions of power that require minimal work, like being landlords, managers, investors, or “thought leaders.” This enables them to maximize their time spent preparing when their next feeding will take place, which is the real labor of their lives.

Vampires are infertile but sexuality does play a role in their lives from time to time.

Histories and Cultures

Vampires are mentioned even in the most ancient records of Braven. Most specifically, urban accounts written by sleuths and professional detectives found strange patterns of both anemia and death by blood loss. Works of fiction and history have been fascinated by vampires ever since.

Notes for Playing as

Vampires can make for an exciting side-quest, mistery thriller or even just a surprise twist. I sometimes like to make a character a vampire even if nothing comes of it, makes it interesting!

Can Alter Reality

Passive: 80 Alchemy*

Analyze: 150 Alchemy

Vampires can undo negative effects dealt to them. They can also use Seeming, which is dispellable.

Ageless and Undead

Passive: 100 Alchemy

Analyze: 170 Alchemy

Vampires cannot age and are animated by powerful chemical reactions. Their blood is blue and they are weak to Conjured Essence (the rune).

A Mysterious Cause...

Passive: 150 Alchemy

Analyze: 220 Alchemy

Vampires are created, not born. Perhaps an unknown creature is involved (see Zamycleus lore).

New Vampire

Dine

1 Minute or 12PT & 4SN

You feed on a location, healing any fresh signs of damage and stopping Bleeding. Every Bleeding you remove counts as [1 Health] consumed.

Open

6PT & 2SN

Damage: [5d6+10 Health]

Info: Bodily Attack (SL), 3 Base PT

Effects: You strike with claws or teeth. This attack is painless and will not wake sleeping targets.

Placate2

9PT & 9SN or 2 Plot Points

Target within [40u] takes [9 Stun]. If used as a defense, the stun applies before the attack is made.

~Passives~

Noctis/Solis, Sadist

At night you gain [+70] to all Grace Maneuvers. During the day you gain [+70] to all Prestige Maneuvers. During Dusk you have both bonuses and during Dawn you have neither.

You have no SN Regen. If you witness a Wound being dealt to any target, you heal [+10 Sanity]. You heal for [2SN] for every [1 Health] you consume from a human target by any means. You sense all targets with Bleeding within [500u].

Level 55

Old Nia (1), The Dead (3), Colonial (3), & Choice (3)

Dine

You feed on a location, healing any fresh signs of damage and stopping Bleeding. Every Bleeding you remove counts as [1 Health] consumed.

Frenzy

30SN

You gain [+6PT] and your move becomes [10/1]. Open becomes painful and now deals [8d6+26 Health + 400 Stamina] damage but will wake sleeping targets. These benefits last two rounds.

Open

6PT & 2SN

Damage: [8d6+24 Health]

Info: Bodily Attack (SL + SL), 3 Base PT

Seeming2

36SN or 5 Plot Points

(Magnify III, Memorized) You appear as another humanoid of similar size and shape and gain [+4d6] to all social maneuvers relevant to that humanoid. This lasts for 60 minutes.

If this is cast during the Day or Dusk, the illusion has a power of [2d100+350], otherwise it has a power of [2d100+100].

Anyone with a passive Awareness greater than the Seeming’s power will notice it is an illusion. Also, this may be dispelled if someone uses Dispel Seeming on you with a Spell Total greater than your Seeming’s power.

Subtle Sway2

16SN or 2 Plot Points

If during the Night or Dusk: Your next Dodge total becomes [290], using Stealth instead of Agility.

If during the Day or Dusk: Add [+125] to your Spell Resist against the next spell you receive. You may only have one use of this benefit at a time and it expires when Dusk ends.

~Passives~

Noctis/Solis, Sadist

At night you gain [+125] to all Grace Maneuvers. During the day you gain [+125] to all Prestige Maneuvers. During Dusk you have both bonuses and during Dawn you have neither.

You have no SN Regen. If you witness a Wound being dealt to any target, you heal [+20 Sanity]. You heal for [5SN] for every [1 Health] you consume from a human target by any means. You sense all targets with Bleeding within [2000u].

Vulpidons

Nimblest

Passive: 30 Nature*

Analyze: 60 Nature

Vulpidons are masters of mobility. They leap great bounds and can glide while falling.

Thunderous Cats

Passive: 50 Nature or 60 Alchemy

Analyze: 80 Nature

Vulpidons can make such powerful noise that they damage things. They are immune to shock.

Sonic Trickery

Passive: 70 Nature or 80 Alchemy

Analyze: 120 Nature

Vulpidons can control pockets of sound and either stop sounds from entering or from exiting a chosen radius. They use this to ambush prey.

“War riders of the south wear coverings on their ears because they battle on wailing hellcats.”

- Sha Stand, VNFC Period, Issue #420, the Complete Collection

Behavior

Vulpidons can appear distant or rude at first, but this can mostly just be attributed to their manners. Generally, vulpidons are clever conversationalists despite not particularly enjoying conversation. They love quiet, as one might expect from a creature with such ears.

For the most part, vulpidons range in personality from warm, wholesome, and quiet to snarky, sarcastic, and disinterested.

Habitat and Life

Vulpidons favor warm climates and have a very poor ability to stave off cold. They will have a litter of kits with a mate they trust but typically only one parent will raise the litter along with that parent’s human companion. Vulpidons rely heavily on human companionship in all manner of life, except when it comes to acquiring food.

Histories and Cultures

Vulpidons typically enjoy the comforts of domestic, human environments. In many southern cultures it is acceptable to let vulpidons live inside homes, most unlike all other beasts of their size. Their cleanliness and independence makes for good companions.

A fun fact: “vulpidon” is the diminutive form of “fox” in the dialect of Gilmish spoken by the inhabitants of the Bush and Furnace Woods (who first domesticated vulpidons). It is a playful insult used to refer to something that has outsmarted you but should not have, a “little fox.” It is also a word of respect as well, in a sense.

Notes for Playing as

Vulpidons can be more than just big house cats or an encounter but a clever villain, recurring trickster, or faithful companion and mount.

Vulpidons are large feline beasts with powerful muscles and a glistening, purply-black coat of short fur and shining purple eyes. Vulpidons are quadrupeds with webbing in the pits of each of their legs, resembling small wings like a flying squirrel might have. They have long whiskers, enormous, triangular ears with pink interior fur, and a tail three times as long as their body. At the end of their tail is a thick, bladed ball of dark bone nearly as large as their head. Their coat is longer along their spine. When they are bored their mind wanders somewhere, they make faint humming sounds and rhythmic meows.

Prestidigitating

Passive: 80 Nature or 100 Awareness

Analyze: 130 Nature

Vulpidons have a powerful metabolism that shrugs off many bad effects and they twitch their tail before making a trick attack (Flinch).

Hate Cold

Passive: 100 Nature or 90 Alchemy

Analyze: 150 Nature

Vulpidon are vulnerable to cold and cold damage.

Astral Somnambulism

Passive: 120 Nature and 120 Essence

Analyze: 190 Nature

Without knowledge of doing so, vulpidons’ essence wanders to those nearby while sleeping. They will give nightmares to anyone planning them harm.

Desonify

15SN

You can alter the properties of sound in an area within [40u] with a radius of [3u]. You may choose one effect: Either no sound may leave the radius that originates within the radius or no sound may enter the radius that originates outside of it. This effect lasts for one round and you may change the location before it expires for [5SN] per shift.

Flail Whip

8PT, Optional: -4PT

Damage: [8 Health + 6d20+300 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (CH-UB), 6 Base PT

Flinch: If [4PT] was spent instead of 8, this attack deals no base health damage but is still calculated as an attack with [6 Base PT] in case it crits (it can still deal critical health damage) or is defended against (Eg. Dodge against it costs 8PT).

Panther’s Bound

3 Uses of Move at Once & 12SN

You leap up to [15u]. You may use Flail Whip at no cost along the way or when you land.

~Passives~

Incredible Reach, Webbed Limbs

Attacks have +2 Melee Range.

You take no falling damage and may optionally glide as you fall, moving [1u] laterally in a direction for every [1u] you fall. Direction chosen must be the same until you land (you cannot pivot).

Groom2

12PT & 50SN or 3 Plot Points

Remove all venom, diseases, bleeding, and spells with a duration or channeled effect from you or your target. If not used on yourself, your target takes [12 Stun] (Groom is a powerful relaxant).

Ruption

12PT & 100 Stamina

Damage: [6 Health + 20d20 Stamina]

Info: Thrown Voice (BL), 80u Range, 6 Base PT

You throw your voice at a location and blast all targets in a [1u] Radius with a thunderous crack. This damages and affects the head of each target in the radius capable of hearing. No defense is made. Ignores Health MIT. Roll [d100+100] for the volume. Targets must add their [Orientation + 50] against the volume. Any result in the negatives is subtracted from all their maneuvers for one round.

~Passives~

Fastidious, Mature Vibrospine, Size Adv/Incredible Reach, Size Disadv, Spiritwalker, Surgical, Webbed Limbs

Crit on a roll of 76-100.

You are immune to Shock Damage but take 100% more damage from Cold attacks. You may use Ruption as an Opportunity on any target that hits you with a ranged attack. You may use Flail Whip as an Opportunity, but it consumes two Opportunities at once. You gain 4 Opportunities per turn.

Huge: Attacks have +3 Melee Range.

Huge: Cannot use defenses against physical attacks from Small-sized and smaller entities. Most moves cost much more PT.

Those sleeping near you who wish to do you harm have nightmares, taking [-100 Med/Rest].

Add [+2d6 Health] damage per Trauma Level.

You take no falling damage and may optionally glide as you fall, moving [1u] laterally in a direction for every [1u] you fall. Direction chosen must be the same until you land (you cannot pivot).

Zamycleus

Zamycleus (pronounced zuh-MAI-klee-us) are shapeshifters that initially just look like an ordinary person. They can be any race, gender, or class of person. When “unshifted,” their true form is bipedal and lanky with pale green to dark yellow skin. They have gaunt limbs. Each foot and hand has only 3 digits, about twice the length of a typical person’s. They have a pointed crest on the back of their skull that sticks back and slightly up (like a pteranodon) with a beak twice as long as this crest on their face. Their mouth is typically agape with a slight smile and full of thousands of crooked teeth, thin as needles. They have four, small, milky white eyes each with no pupil or iris, one on each side of their head and two in front. They have two large, pure black eyes on the back of their head, under their crest.

Vampiric Spawner

Passive: 150 Alchemy

Analyze: 220 Alchemy (other targets)

Something powerful turns folks into vampires.

Folks are Aging Fast

Passive: 160 Alchemy or 150 Common

Analyze: 230 Alchemy (other targets)

Some members of this community age faster than they should. What is this horrible ailment?

Paralytic Memory Loss

Passive: 180 Alchemy or 160 Common

Analyze: 240 Alchemy

A mysterious creature or phenomenon is capable of paralyzing folks and wiping their memories. It’s a trauma-induced memory repression.

The Koda’s Quest

Passive: 200 Alchemy or 200 Nature

Analyze: 270 Nature (other targets)

Koda seek to destroy horrific shapeshifting monsters that feed on youth. They might know more.

Must Shift to Live

Passive: 200 Alchemy

Analyze: (Cannot Analyze)

Ancient, mirthic, alchemy research titled the Zamycleus Experiments shows special beings were crafted as an attempt to find eternal youth. Their unstable bodies were given the ability to shed and morph their physical form. They must continually find new forms to morph into or they die.

Zamycleus Age Fast Too

Passive: 200 Alchemy

Analyze: 270 Alchemy

Zamycleus and their shifted form both age quickly, meaning one of the victims of fast aging could actually be the Zamycleus.

Non-Magical Abilities

Passive: 210 Alchemy or 210 Essence

Analyze: (Cannot Analyze)

The Zamycleus Experiments were given many abilities, all of which could not be countered, detected, or controlled using magical means. They became too clever and too powerful to contain and all escaped. Research halted. Most records are destroyed.

Meticulous Methods

Passive: 220 Alchemy*

Analyze: 290 Alchemy

Zamycleus can morph their stats to adapt to their current needs.

They must unshift their body in order to steal youth. When they consume enough youth, they can shed their old alternative form and gain a fresh, new form to shift into. Their new form matches the target whose youth they stole.

Undead Masters

Passive: 220 Alchemy or 220 Essence

Analyze: (Cannot Analyze)

On a rare occasion someone has a fatal response the youth-draining ability of a Zamycleus, instantly dying and becoming undead. The Zamycleus infuses them with their essence, giving them a purpose: to feed on blood, as a way to divert attention from the real mastermind.

The Red Touch

Passive: 230 Alchemy

Analyze: 300 Alchemy

Zamycleus’ unshifted hands contain Red Poison, which glows when exposed to any ailment. Zamycleus move their hands over someone before feeding, to avoid gaining illnesses. It appears that they will not feed on anyone who is sick, even if it means they eventually starve to death. Perhaps this is the most surefire way to survive: make everyone in a community sustain illness for long enough.

“It is unlikely a complete copy of the methods and results exist for the Zamycleus Experiments.”

- Aaryahi Chakrabarti, Ancient Crimes and Early Golemics

Behavior

Zamycleus behave with complete disregard for the lives of others. They are meticulous when planning and utterly psychotic. As serial killers and serial manipulators, they are generally concerned with their own pleasures and needs.

Despite these reprehensible characteristics, zamycleus have enough brilliance to emulate people perfectly. This sociopathic genius could mean that anyone, even the most caring and loving person might be a zamycleus in disguise. They are the ultimate performers and fakers.

Of course, they will almost never fight outright but will attempt to escape whenever possible. They have an enormous amount of pride and rage, but their self control will only show these unless things have become too risky and they are moving in for the kill.

Habitat and Life

Zamycleus take the form of someone new once every twenty years. It takes them an entire year to successfully steal someone’s form and youth, typically sneaking into their chambers every night. On top of that, they will rapidly age during their last year until they can complete their youth consumption ritual. This means that the year before a zamycleus is going to replace their form is the most important time for them.

During this important year, zamycleus don’t feed on the same target each night but stagger their options. By having up to six potential candidates going at the same time, they will be safer in case things don’t go according to plan (like if one gets sick, dies, or moves away).

While not in their active, youth-stealing year, they invest an incredible amount of time and energy canvassing a city, looking for their next victims. Their ideal victims are not wanderers or adventurers, young enough to age twenty years in a single year and still be healthy, and in good health overall. This means that they tend to target middle class or upper class, land-owning gentry most often. These targets have better health and are more likely to stay in one place for a longer period of time.

But even so, zamycleus still feed on a variety of different people depending on the situation. They prefer the security of a biodiverse diet: if a whole community becomes affected by an ailment, the zamycleus is at risk. Feeding on diverse groups of people allows them the best chance for a good candidate at the end of their year.

Zamycleus cannot reproduce, which means only a small number of them exist. However, they do produce followers (vampires) and can have a significant number of these at any given time. Their exact relationship to and power over these individuals varies from zamycleus to zamycleus.

Histories and Cultures

For the most part, the world has no idea that such a monster even exists. Zamycleus are leagues ahead of any that try to catch them and there is very little reason they could ever get caught.

That being the case, koda do have a tradition called the Quest, where they are trying to save the world from hidden secrets and shape-stealers. Despite this, most koda have never actually seen a zamycleus.

Different koda historians have different accounts of what the shape-stealers are and what they have done. Still, it can be assumed that if the two ever crossed paths, a zamycleus would do everything in their power to kill the koda as quickly as possible.

Notes for Playing as

It could be fun to build a strange and secret society of vampires, run by a zamycleus. Perhaps they are competing with the local demons for blood and turf? Perhaps they are hoping to create the ultimate domestication of human cattle? Who knows! They are definitely evil though.

As a zamycleus, you will want to run and evade as much as possible. Stay fluid. The only murders you commit should be carefully planned. A zamycleus is rarely impulsive.

Also, while zamycleus are insanely strong and meant for high level encounters, you still shouldn’t rely on luck to turn players into a vampires. It’s not added as a mechanic on purpose (only plot-driven).

Zamycleus

Level 88

+30 Plot Points

Languages

Demonic (3), Dark-Tongue (3), Old Nia (3), The Dead (3), & all human languages (3)

Size: Medium

Occupies: 1x1x2 (1u wide, 1u deep, 2u tall).

Consume Youth

1 Hour & 36SN

You gaze at a target. If they are free of poisons, venoms, diseases, and curses, they gain [30 Marks of Consumption] and grow [Two Months] older. If you do not use Consume Youth on them again within [3 Days], you will lose all Marks of Consumption on them and their youth will return.

Flay

12PT

Damage: [96 Health + 12d20+200 Stamina]

Info: Bodily Attack (SL + SL), 6 Base PT

Probe

1 Minute

You hold your hand near a target and detect any poisons, venoms, diseases, and curses on them.

Morph2

1000Stam or 3 Plot Points

Choose one physical stat (Physique, Wellness, Grace, or Prowess). All of its maneuvers gain [+200]. Lasts until replaced. Only one at a time.

Shape-Steal

24PT

If you have used Consume Youth on a target for at least one year and you have at least [3650 Marks of Consumption] against them, you gain the [20 Years of Youth] that they lost. Their appearance and abilities (at time time of using this) become your new Shift form. You also heal [365 Sanity].

Attack d100+100 (Bodily Attack)

Defense (See Abilities), 175 (=PT, Dodge)

S. Resist 276, Lore Type: Alchemy

Move 7/2, +2 INI 50 PT 24

Stam 10000 SN 400,+80 DH 450

Head

MIT 10 | 50%

Evade +20

Health 18

R Arm

MIT 10 | 50%

Evade +10

Health 30

R Leg

MIT 10 | 50%

Evade 0

Health 50

Chest

MIT 10 | 50%

Evade 0

Health 75

L Arm

MIT 10 | 50%

Evade +10

Health 30

L Leg

MIT 10 | 50%

Evade 0

Health 50

Traumatic Gaze2

100 Sanity, Optional: +5 Plot Points

The pupils on your eyes appear. Anything that you gaze upon becomes paralyzed as if all time stood still. You gain [6d6+6 Potential] to use freely before anyone else can take another action.

Repression: If [5 Plot Points] were spent, roll [d100+400] for the power of your Gaze. Any target in your sight whose [Courage + Willpower + 50] is less than your Gaze’s power will forget encountering you once you leave their presence.

~Passives~

Immaculate, Timeless, True Poison, Shift/Unshift, Uncanny Horror

Crit on a roll of 6-100. You have 360 degree sight and can see in pitch blackness.

Receive 25% Stun, Bleeding, and Sanity Damage.

If you deal any Health Damage, your target contracts the Red Poison. See Green Book for details.

Shift: You take on the shape you have stolen. You use their character sheet to determine the additional abilities you gain. While shifted, you use their Physique, Wellness, Grace, and Prowess (except whatever stat you have used Morph on).

Unshift: You lose the abilities gained from Shift but now may use Consume Youth, Flay, Probe, and Shape-Steal. (Morph and Traumatic Gaze may be used in either form.)

Any human that encounters you while you are unshifted has their Sanity reduced to [1] until you leave their presence, then it returns. Any sanity they lose during this time is still lost when their sanity returns to them. If a target already has less than [1 Sanity], they are unaffected.

Physique 5

Arm Muscle 50

Leg Muscle 50

Wellness 5

Med/Rest 75

Toughness 75

Grace 5

Balance/Steer 50

Dexterity 50

Missile/Thrown 25

Stealth 100

Willpower 175

Zombies

The disease that afflicts ghouls (humanoid zombies) causes massive brain hemorrhaging and splitting of the skull, resulting in total hair loss, corneal opacity (white or grey eyes), bleeding ears, nose, mouth, and dramatic contusions from the top of the head down. The hematomata (bruising) of the skull starts at the top of the head (the source of the skull split) and forms thick vein or drip-like bruising down the head and face. Ghouls can wear any sort of clothing or armor, but do not wield any weapons.

Already Dead

Passive: 30 Alchemy* or 40 Common

Analyze: 60 Alchemy

Anyone afflicted by this disease has already died. The disease simply reanimates their corpse.

Tireless

Passive: 40 Alchemy or 60 Common

Analyze: 70 Alchemy

Zombies do not need to sleep, cannot be knocked out, and do not bleed. They cannot lose Stamina.

Brainless

Passive: 50 Alchemy and 50 Essence

Analyze: 100 Alchemy

Zombies are immune to social maneuvers and whispered spells (portaled spells work). They cannot lose Sanity but have no intellectual ability.

“The ghoul: a case study in disease or foul magic. But be wary, either means something dangerous.”

- Ri Richus, Alchemy

Behavior

Zombies typically move slowly, which is a result of being older corpses, afflicted with permanent but mild rigor mortis (poor nutrition mixed with no bacterial or chemical decomposition). This means that zombies which move quickly and have more strength are likely freshly deceased.

Ghouls are savagely interested in feeding on non-infected human corpses. This desire (presumed to be a result of viral or parasitic motivation) now controls their corpse.

Other than feeding, ghouls will wander about looking to kill or feed and have a keen knack for detecting and tracking humans.

Habitat and Life

Ghouls seem roam all over Braven but tend towards more rural areas, especially those where the dead are buried rather than burned. Some theories exist around why they are more common in rural areas, but it is likely that the unknown pathogen propogates in non-urban environments. The other contributing factor to their prevalence in these areas is due to the availability of corpses in graveyards, as opposed to areas where different death rites are practiced (non-burial).

Histories and Cultures

Ghouls have been predominantly recorded by medical annals, reports, and studies first noted in the first age in Gamin (in the Ancient’s Sod).

Ghouls are commonly employed symbolically in fiction and politics to represent gormless, individualistic, selfish, or lazy people or opponents.

Notes for Playing as

If your players are meta-gaming too much, feel free to remove the head-wounds-kill feature. Try checking out Scudgie’s lore for interesting ideas.

Incurable but Killable

Passive: 60 Alchemy or 80 Common

Analyze: 110 Alchemy

Zombies cannot be cured. A Wound to their head or depleting their Death Health will kill them.

Terminal Vector

Passive: 90 Alchemy

Analyze: 140 Alchemy

The disease afflicting zombies is not contagious.

Could be a “Husk”

Passive: 120 Alchemy or 120 Essence

Analyze: 170 Alchemy

There are illegal spells for controlling corpses. Using Dispel, Split, or Track Essence (or other spells) could help determine if a ghoul was the result of a disease or some nefarious human intervention.

Ripe Ghoul

Bite

3PT, Must have grabbed target

Damage: [6 Health + 3d20+185 Stamina]

Info: Bite Attack (ML), 3 Base PT

No attack roll is made, this automatically hits. Damage is dealt to the same location grabbed.

Grab

6PT, Optional: -3PT

Grab target with both arms, dealing no damage. Target may defend and use Struggle against your strength of [d100+75].

Optional: If only 3PT was spent, you may grab with a strength of [d100+50] instead.

~Passives~

Ghoulish, Keen Nose, Soft Head

You do not need to sleep, cannot be knocked out or bleed, do not lose Stamina or Sanity, and are immune to social maneuvers and whispered spells.

+50 to Perception and Tracking maneuvers against humanoids. Can smell up to 1 kilometer.

Receiving a wound to your head is fatal.

Attack d100+50 (Bodily Attack)

Defense (Will not defend against attacks)

S. Resist 79, Lore Type: Alchemy

Move 2/3 INI 6 PT 6

Stam N/A SN N/A DH 45

Evade 0

Health 40

Bite

3PT, Must have grabbed target

Damage: [1d6+8 Health + 3d20+215 Stamina]

Info: Bite Attack (ML), 3 Base PT

No attack roll is made, this automatically hits. Damage is dealt to the same location grabbed.

Grab2

6PT, Optional: -3PT

Grab target with both arms, dealing no damage. Target may defend and use Struggle against your strength of [d100+120].

Optional: If only 3PT was spent, you may grab with a strength of [d100+80] instead.

Note: Both the 6PT and 3PT versions of this ability may be used defensively against melee attacks. Will target the limb making the attack.

~Passives~

Ghoulish, Keen Nose, Soft Head

You do not need to sleep, cannot be knocked out or bleed, do not lose Stamina or Sanity, and are immune to social maneuvers and whispered spells.

+50 to Perception and Tracking maneuvers against humanoids. Can smell up to 1 kilometer.

Receiving a wound to your head is fatal.
